author: NoahNeedleman
content:
So at the urging of Cian & Rauirí and a few other good friends, I took a full 3 months off when my daughter was born. During my paternity leave, my creative outlets were cooking, and photography. 

Photos are great cause you can snag a moment and then come back to it later to edit, cooking more difficult cause it takes time you might not always have. 

Well in typical captial C Creative fashion, i dug deep into it. I did a LOT of research and made some purchases and practiced a lot. Got some beautiful photos and captured some important memories. Really grateful for it. 

All that’s just backstory to say- everywhere else on the internet SUCKS. 

Reddit, Facebook, anywhere there are communities of people who are “trying to help,” it’s just full of tone deaf assholes with little info and a lot of bullshit to spew. And even the smart ones are 99% of the time tactless. 

Guys & girls, thank you for still being here. Best water cooler in the world: LWMR. 

Also I wish we had a photography channel.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
...completely unrelated to anything  but on my mind this morning

Something I've said here (maybe too) often is that approaching the work in a loving way is a real unlock. Love being a quaity of a attention, a way of meeting things. It might not be obvious but it can start small and grow out embracing many more aspects of what we do

I mastered an album a few months back for a phenomenal indie artist, @Rob Domos and I both absolutely loved the music and the overall experience. The artist's team came back this week with a last minute request to remaster what was probably my favorite track with an added feature from a legacy artist. It's kind of mind bending how much better it is

Rob and I spent some time yesterday just appreciating that someone (the artist, manager, A&R?) actually thought up the idea of this feature and made it happen. I was so content with what it was but someone somewhere was like *"you know what would be sick ..."* and made it real. And now the world gets to receive something beyond what we could have imagined, something we didn't even know we needed

Just focussing our attention on that for 2 mins in the hall yesterday made the day better and put some gas in the tank. There are so many challenges in what we do, it really helps to take time to focus attention on the jewels strewn everywhere too. They are not always immediately obvious

author: BatMeckley
content:
God I love this discord. 
To me 90% of the reason big producers are paying many thousands a day to be in a studio the past 15-20 years is to just not have to worry about shit. Anyone can make a record at home these days; part of being in an “actual” studio is the cocoon of creativity. If the assistant takes more than a couple of minutes to patch anything in, bring up the piano, or recommend the best Thai place in town, they’re blowing it. I had an assistant once at this place famous for making cookies on site, bring me my normal plate of cookies I always ask for and while I was comping I ate half of one, put it back on the plate, and continued working. He didn’t say a word, got up, grabbed the plate, and disappeared for a few minutes and came back. “Hey man, I know you normally house the entire plate of cookies so when you put that one back I checked with the kitchen and last week I guess they changed the cookie recipe, and they’re gonna make em like they used to for you.” 😂😂. I asked for that dude every session after, less for the cookies but more for the insane attention to detail and telepathy. One of max’s engineers started as a Conway assistant, and as good of an engineer as he was he also prepped the best Hookahs and was just a great hang. Max ended up hiring him for his own studio. We’re in a people business, try to be attentive and a good person to have around, for all the reasons that go beyond knowing how to set an attack on an 1176. 

The flip side is, if you’re booking a studio as a producer, the assistants are what really make the studio run. Treat them well. Know their names. Give them credit. No assistant on any session I ever did paid for their own meal, they got what the artist got.  They most of the time got engineer credits. Help them along. As with all things, mutual respect goes a long way.

author: NoahNeedleman
content: “Nobody tells this to people who are beginners, I wish someone told me. All of us who do creative work, we get into it because we have good taste. But there is this gap. For the first couple years you make stuff, it’s just not that good. It’s trying to be good, it has potential, but it’s not. But your taste, the thing that got you into the game, is still killer. And your taste is why your work disappoints you. A lot of people never get past this phase, they quit. Most people I know who do interesting, creative work went through years of this. We know our work doesn’t have this special thing that we want it to have. We all go through this. And if you are just starting out or you are still in this phase, you gotta know its normal and the most important thing you can do is do a lot of work. Put yourself on a deadline so that every week you will finish one story. It is only by going through a volume of work that you will close that gap, and your work will be as good as your ambitions. And I took longer to figure out how to do this than anyone I’ve ever met. It’s gonna take awhile. It’s normal to take awhile. You’ve just gotta fight your way through.” - Ira Glass

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Re; Brauer workshop

-First 2 days were nothing technical, the 1st conversation he brought up was about TM and how meditation in general has helped him.
-Everything is feel-based, most technical Q's for the first 2 and a half days got the same reply: "It doesn't matter to me, i don't care what the thing is long as it feels good". 
-MHB actually seems to leave the planet while he's mixing, it's wild how immediate he gets into that space. Seemed to go way past "i love mixing and here's all the reasons i'm the shit" and it was inspiring to see the ego leave the equation. His decades of experience are playing directly into his ability to access the story of the song and present it in a compelling, live-feeling way. He mixes from inside the song and performs. Well, he does discovery, then shapes the sounds, then performs just about everything on faders.
-The biggest wake up call to me is that a lot of moves i've made on mixes did not have a good reason behind them. So continuing to ask "why" as I work is gonna be important, because I have to start catching myself and adjusting when the answer to "why" is "because someone said this preset is cool" or "because this is what I do to a vocal/guitar/drums". I feel music very deeply, it's why i got into this, but I feel like i've been poisoned against trusting that instinct and convinced that what we do is a technical job. I'm done being an observer of the art, i want to be bold.
-It's critical to build trust with clients right away, you can't assume anything in what they understand about how you feel. Telling them you love the song and you're excited to mix it is important, and never blaming production/artist/anything else for the mix being less than what it should be. never okay to say "i did my best", because that gives you an out and implies somebody else could do it better
-Therefore, you must believe when you sit down to mix that nobody is gonna interpret this song better than you.
-Generally i'm skeptical to just take on someone else's "method" and start operating in that space just becuase of the success they've had with it. Putting this week into practice is going to mean using his template to get reps in, listening and feeling and interacting in a new way and letting my brain "level up", if you will, then zooming out and making it my own.


I can distill this more and want to share about a couple other specifics, but I just realized I grabbed someone else's notebook by mistake when I left on the last day so I'll need to have them mail mine back to me.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’m convinced that the root of most of our suffering is the gaps between who we think we are, who we actually are, and who we want to be.

Everyone has done something awful in their life, and our lives are filled with the compromises that define our true morality. I think smacking your wife around is awful, but I still enjoy the Beatles and Lennon’s work. We would burn at the stake a grown man that sleeps with 15 year olds, yet David Bowie is still hailed as an icon. “I think child labor is bad and we should take a stand against it!!” I type on my iPhone while wearing my Nikes.

We don’t want to admit how many things that should be deal breakers to us we’re actually ultimately ok with, as evidenced by what we ACTUALLY DO with our lives, vs what we would like to think we’d do.

author: BatMeckley
content: But to come full circle, and in line with our talk at Cian’s the other night, my Lol’s on here are more for the 980 people on here that are registered but don’t contribute, or aren’t as active. There are GUARANTEED aspiring engineers, mixers and producers on here that are taking what we say far too seriously, and I feel a genuine responsibility to not entirely dash their dreams because they just spent every dime they had on PMCs or their beats suck. It’s a tricky to path to navigate between taking what we do seriously, without taking ourselves too seriously. It’s a people business, and I do my best to embody on this forum that I’ve found the best way to work consistently in this industry is to be able to take a joke, make a joke, and keep putting out good work. Which I think is FAR more important than if you picked PMCs or ATCs.

author: philbarnes
content:
One of my favorite TLA experiences is when I (unknowingly) fucked up a drum edit in a song I sent him to mix about 6 years ago. 

Got a voicemail from a South Beach number that said "Phil! Tom Lord-Alge here. Hey, thank you for those stems. Give me a call when you get a chance would ya?" 

Not knowing my demise, I thought I would flex and call him in front of my gf on speakerphone where the first words out of his mouth were: "Thanks for sending those stems so fast. But these drums... are absolutely FUCKED. I could fix it for you, but I'm not going to, you're a professional engineer, figure it out." 

Needless to say I stayed up all night figuring it out, found my mistake and I like to think we're on better terms now.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Tl;dr- where you are matters as much as who you are. 

I’m also from a small town, moved to LA trying to get famous and got my ass handed to me by artists who were better looking & more talented and yet were still struggling to be seen. But I kept at it because I’m tenacious, (read: delusional, as all artists must be.)

I was able to work *for* some of those artists cause I had a diverse skillset, and I was full time music after about 4 years, by the time I was 26. Doing gigs at hotels and playing guitar or recording for other people, teaching guitar, leading music at churches, all the while pouring evening last ounce of money & energy into my artist career, until my last real artist project broke up the week we were supposed to sign our first record deal. I was 36. 

That’s when I moved to Nashville and really gave myself over to music directing and producing and writing for other artists. I did it as a consolation while I regrouped to find my next thing, but for some reason, when I made the move all the sudden my whole career made sense to me. 

As it turns out, my real joy comes not from the sound of my own voice, but from helping others find theirs. When I acquiesced to that very real, very culturally counterintuitive calling, I thrived. 

All the sudden I was playing music with and for a bunch of my heroes, and all my friends who were artists starting getting famous. And (shocker) I was really glad I wasn’t one of them. 

I always thought that my calling was to help people feel less alone in the world, and that the music I made was the vehicle for that calling. In the end, it turns out it was the relationships i built through music that were the real vehicle.  

It took me a long time to figure out who I was, and the cities I was in played a huge role in that story. Nashville built its whole industry on people who want to *help* artists, not just *be* artists. 

I miss LA every day but I’m in the right place. So, my friend, where is the right place for you?

author: LAPhill
content:
It's really hard to make decisions when you feel like our back is up against the wall. We've all experienced some degree of this, one way or another, and a lot of it comes down to personal tolerance for risk and resilience to weather dry spells, as well as our individual life circumstances.

There's no medal for going months without income. If you need to find a day job or side hustle to stay afloat, that's not failure. That's responsible. If the feeling of your wife's support is making you feel guilty, then it might be a signal to take some action to address that feeling. Music will always be there, and it's not an all-or-nothing proposition. 

I'm not trying to prescribe the way out of this, but give yourself some grace and permission to navigate it. You're not less-than because you take time to address your personal life and finances in the midst of building your career, you're human.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Ok, here’s another perspective based on some recent experience

Classic scenario that’s played out a thousand times. “What do you do?” - I work in music. “Oh, what exactly?” - I’m a studio guy, a Mastering Engineer, I finish records. “Oh! Have you worked with anyone I’d know?”

For the longest time the answer to that question was NO. And so the question felt like “Are you somebody?”

But now I can answer Taylor Swift. *Everyone* knows Taylor…

But you know what’s happened? I realized that what they were asking all along is “Am I somebody?”

They are working changing my oil or whatever and looking for a little berry on the tree, or a shell on the beach. Something to take home that day, something to lift them up a little. “I met a guy who does XYZ today”. I do it all the time. My neighbor drives the Mars Rover. I mean, she goes to work, logs in and drives the fucking Mars Rover. And that is amazing. And being proximate to it makes me just a little more special in that silly human way

So, a little empathy for the shell gathering normies

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Growing up in Ireland, without PP I wouldn’t have known that making records could be a legitimate career.

It showcased real life *professionals* working at a high level, and was my introduction to the discourse around the industry. Having only experienced studio work as a cottage industry up to that point, PP opened my eyes to avenues I could pursue that I wouldn’t have known even existed otherwise (recording engineer is different to mixing engineer is different to producer is different to songwriter??!). It all seems very rudimentary now, but I was starting from literally nothing in a place with few (if any?) visible role models.

I learned so much from it on a technical level - from basic stuff like what a Pultec is and how people use it (connecting the dots between my cracked Waves bundle - Puigtec and who tf JJP was), what “a vocal chain” might look like and the purpose of each stage…

True, the interviews did become unbearable, but there was a golden era between eps around 30-90 at a time when outside of working in the studio world, there weren’t many other sources of good information from people who were really doing it.

Huge appreciation for Dave, and I hope he and his family get the support they need.

author: cian riordan
content:
Rich Costey doing a Q&A on the gearspace forum right now and it's just amazing. On mixing the Rage Renegades album with Rick Rubin: 

"Rick called me up after I worked on Fiona Apple "When The Pawn..". I learned a lot from him, primarily how to work from instinct instead of intellect. He would often make mix suggestions which I thought were bad ideas but I would of course do them because it's what he wanted, and they worked. He really did listen like a teenager, it was always simply whether or not he was getting off on something. If he wasn't, he'd make very clear suggestions on how to make something better. Sometimes he'd just say the mix sucked and to start over (only once). Sometimes the recording itself had issues and he would just deal with what's there. I think that turned into a serious strength of his- working with what's in front of him. We still keep in touch from time to time"

I have many thoughts from this week, happy to share whatever if anyone feels like that would be helpful. author: bobby k
content:
Most of my years in music have felt like groundwork-laying years. Just because your credits playlist isn’t looking the way you’d like doesn’t mean that growth wasn’t happening. I would challenge you to reflect on where you started 2025 and where you are now and take inventory of what growth or lessons you experienced. 

The most rewarding bits of this year for me wouldn’t make sense to post about. Paid off my first business loan. Improved the efficiency of signal flow in my studio. Learned to fix some gear. Stood up for myself in a hard conversation with some assholes trying to rip me off. Got out of the UAD ecosystem. 

None of that I’m posting about or adding to a playlist, but it feels just as essential (or more) to my business than the songs that got released.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Hey @everyone. A quick PSA about form on this server: 

As this server becomes more populated the quantity of daily/hourly posts are increasing. This is a great development and we love to see lively, thoughtful conversations. 

With this increase in posting comes a lot of information that can sometimes be overwhelming to manage and parse. Especially when a channel has two different conversations happening on top of each other. I think we've all casually opened the app at one point and seen "40+ unread messages" and been taken aback by the sheer amount of convo that we now have to catch up on.

Moving forward I ask the following from everyone:

*1. If you see a conversation starting to ramp up use Discord’s **Create Thread** feature to fork off the conversation into a self-contained thread. (see attached pic)
2. Give the thread a descriptive name.
3. Continue all follow-up posts within the new thread.*

author: cian riordan
content: I’ve spent that last two years almost exclusively mixing and I’m starting to feel a bit bored. For whatever reason, the lane I’ve ended up in (and the skill set I’ve honed) is taking less than ideal recordings and productions, and making them sound professional. I often find myself thinking “if I was recording this, I would have done xyz”. So it’s time to get back into the studio and get things right from the start. Mixing full time is also quite lonely. Pre covid, I was used to being surrounded by interesting, creative people… now most of my interactions are remote. And despite Jon and some other people’s thoughts, I find in person revision sessions to be inefficient and usually unfruitful. So, time to record some stuff.

author: cian riordan
content:
The take-way from all this blibber blabber is that I went in expecting to be trusted immediately. I wanted to show off… to establish ‘status’ as Ruairi put it. But it took years of patiently learning the ropes at the highest level to be trusted by the folks in the highest circles. I look back upon that now and I’m still amazed that I was paid to do that. It was essentially like a paid college degree in making records.

So now when I go into studios with a big client, I see the assistant through those eyes. I’m kind but communicative. If they can hang in the back and figure out how I work, anticipate breaks — get the menu book ready — know that we’re going to change gears — start setting up for that — then they get looped in. They get my running commentary on what techniques I’m doing. They get the inside baseball… “I wish they fired this fucking drummer”. 

I agree with Ruairi that this type of coming up through the ranks is a loss for up and comers. It was tried and true way to make people understand the ins and outs of studio technique, etiquette, professionalism. I’m glad I got to ride one of the last waves of it. I wouldn’t be here making records at this level if it weren’t for the opportunities I had at the bottom levels of the industry.

author: Zakhiggins

America is a blank canvas for the self motivated, and a drowning pool for people who feel like the state should take care of them. author: BatMeckley
content: I feel like virtually all of us are dealing with mental health issues in one way or the other. For me, getting out of my own way is not over analyzing every step I take and re-litigating every mix decision to the point where I end up only releasing a handful of songs every few years.  At some point, no matter what our individual issues are, we have to log off the internet and actually make music instead of constantly talking about all of the individual reasons why we can’t. Sometimes, at least in my case, we get analysis paralysis because it’s easier than actually hitting record and just doing the damn thing. There was this meme going around last week that was something along the line of “oh hey task that only took me 15 minutes but I’ve been putting off for 5 months”. I think we can all get caught up in bathing in the 58 reasons why we can’t do something instead of just locking on to the few reasons we can, because it’s safer to live in our potential than our actual.

author: Rob Domos
content:
All of these questions from the role of fun and risk to future advice to what I’m changing this year etc. all has the same answer for me. 

A few months ago I had a dream I keep thinking about: I’m in a classroom, and the teacher is projecting photographs students had taken onto the whiteboard. When she gets to one of mine (a picture I hadn’t turned in but she somehow had found), all of the colors were bizarre and unrealistic. I’d performed an experiment where I tried to achieve neutral whites by picking only yellow subjects and shooting them with a maximally cold white balance straight to film. It didn’t look real, but it looked novel, and it ended up being loved and appreciated by everyone there. 

The “safe harbors” person I’ve become wouldn’t take such a picture, let alone publish it. I gravitate towards topics like monitoring because with physics, there’s a clear cut North Star, and I can certainly get closer to my aim by removing problems. But that’s not how love works, or creating a sense of awe, or even nutrition. You have to add things. You can’t just take away.

I think this is the point in my life where I start to abandon ideas of “correct” and start to go where love and curiosity lead me, both inside of art and outside of it. 

It’s not about zapping resonances. It’s about creating resonances.

author: cian riordan
content:
"Sorry about the late night duplicate file, I did this track after six other people because I'm rushing as a team player.   I delivered as promised up front as we are all in overtime now to make it great.  *CLIENT* is happy with your work and with mine and we are all working overtime together.   Apologies also, I know there were some annoying ticks in there with some of the revised files. Still not sure why this one session did that. 

Of course I don't listen to every single file, post rendering.   We render and send 500-1000 files a month with the revisions on the 200-300 monthly songs that I do.  Team players don't ask such things on CC.  I work usually 7 days a week for 40-50 people a month, and making them happy with great masters is job #1.  Perfectionism is not a part of that process.    Software makes mistake, and that's ok.    People make mistakes and that's ok.   Mixes and masters should never aim for perfect, they should aim to connect, aim for humanity.  

Perfection is not the goal here, it's musicality and teamwork.  I'm sorry your ears suffered that horrible popping, but please, be cool. "

author: BatMeckley
content:
I think I’m more along the lines of Seth, in that I firmly believe that in an ultra competitive field like making music, if you don’t have that fire within you, the faith in yourself to keep going even if someone doubts you, it’s probably not going to work out very well for you long term. Success in our (and frankly most fields) isn’t given, it’s taken. There were so many people, some incredibly close to me, that insisted I was going fail. Frankly, if they hadn’t, I don’t know if I would’ve had the success I’ve had so far. When you’re flat broke, behind on rent, car is broken, and no one is hiring… “fuck you” can be an awfully powerful motivator.

That doesn’t mean it’s our job to spit on others dreams… I believe in proactively reaching out to the up and comers because believing in someone and supporting them can be incredibly powerful. But if you NEED that kind of validation constantly to get the work done… not a good sign.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Also, (having not looked into the details on Apple Classical yet) I think that could be a good idea. Classical music is an organizational nightmare right now on streaming services because classical music gets filed/classified way differently than pop music that has a single, definitive recording.

If I'm hunting for a recording of 'The Rite of Spring' there could be 40 different versions available to pick from. We need finer criteria to specify which version we're seeking. I need tools to search by the following: Piece name, movement, conductor, orchestra, year of recording, remastered/original, etc. The list goes on. Classical listeners need that level of granularity because the different recordings/interpretations are a big deal in the classical world.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
There’s a few questions there so one at a time I guess. I’m just going to answer what you asked directly, and maybe this week I can take a shot at answering what I think are the underlying themes..

**How do you approach your craft now, in terms of attention to detail**

Nothing has changed in terms of my attention to detail, everything gets the same love as it always did. The stakes for errors have gone up - when they are manufacturing 100k copies of vinyl then you have to be sure it’s error free

**Do you reject artists if they approach you to “Master my album i’ll pay you whatever you want” if you think the level of their sound might not honour your history with all these artists**

I don’t reject *anyone* who can pay my rate. I don’t vet clients on a “how will you make me look?” basis, I’m a service provider to them. There are very very occasionally mismatches where I’ll say “happy to do this but I think you’d be better served by XYZ”, an example being someone coming to me with EDM who wants really intense processing - another girl or guy steeped in that genre will serve them better

**How does it feel having a connection to these artists?**

It feels really nice to be trusted with people’s art, when someone like a St. Vincent says “yeah, this is good” it matters to me, she has great ears and taste so it feels good to hit a mark

It’s also very special to hear these things come out of the speaker for the first time - I’ll never forget hearing Nick Cave, or Taylor or Lana in the room for the first time. It’s a privilege to be trusted with their art

**but does it ever happen that you are wanting more?”**

I’m human and can be reliably trusted to do all the silly human things like being greedy, insecure, fearful etc. but every year I get a little better at living a better way, and around the music in particular my operating principles “The why” feel better and truer than they ever have

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I respect this take, but I disagree. 

Amending roles ex post facto is a shitty move, but fighting for the byline when no one looks up credits anyway… there’s just no upside. 

I just did “additional production” on a track that will be credited as “guitars,” because that’s what it took to get the song over the finish line. Now the song is gonna be a single that’s going to radio for the artist. 

Would it “look better” if I was credited properly? Sure. But everyone who matters knows exactly what I did for the project, and that’s how, at 42, I was able to take almost 4 months off for paternity leave and have the artists I work with waiting for me instead of finding other producers to work with.

author: Zach Hughes
content:
Coincidentally I was exploring a similar idea this morning. I'm on a David Bohm kick and was reading his book 'On Dialogue' and recently finished his 'On Creativity' (would highly recommend both).

In 'On Dialogue' he gives an example I think can be repurposed here. Imagine a song being presented to us. An external signal. When it reaches us it makes contact with what Bohm calls the "whole movement of thought". The thinking and feeling apparatus within us is activated. Thoughts and 'felts' are said to be fundamentally created from memory. Upon contact a 're-presentation' is created where the activity of our thought and feeling reforms the event internally. The 'net presentation' is the fused result. 'Mis-representation' occurs when we mistake the 'net presentation' for the original.

I was thinking on all this and how it might connect to your comment from yesterday, "I told Jon that I don't think he's ever brought more to an album, but also left less of his fingerprints on it".

Bohm brings up Michael Polanyi's idea of tacit knowledge. This is the always running in the background implicit structure we attend to music from, which makes 're-presentation' possible. This includes nostalgia for records we love, perceptual training, bodily memory, tolerance for brightness, etc... Implied here is that this is something you cannot turn off but can cultivate greater awareness off in disciplined participation with art. Polanyi says we attend from subsidiaries to a focal whole. If you start attending to your own sonic fingerprint as the focal object, the structure may collapse. So perhaps Jon was able to integrate a remarkable tacit contribution while being sensitive to the pre-existing structure and coherence of the whole. Maybe coherence and truth have similar meanings here?

Downstream of the artist's origination maybe 'truth' in record making is deep tacit integration, suspending egoic domination, and sensitivity to the internal structure / coherence of the original whole.

author: cian riordan
content: Eventually I caught the hang of things. I started to study the rhythms of the sessions, what order people would file in every morning. I knew the singer liked coffee one way, another guy did something else… I’d start to have that stuff ready. Instead of chumming it up with the band trying to fend off boredom while Eric was mid task, I stuck around on the couch… watching patiently. Those were the moments where he would start looping me into what he was doing, explaining his techniques. Before I knew it, I could start anticipating what he would need next. Someone mentions trying some vocals on a thing? I immediately got going on setting up a mic, getting headphones, even starting to dial in a mix on the headphone box. Percussion? Grab the trunk of junk and start laying out potential options. Once I started actually being useful, I’d be given real tasks. “Hey, do you think you could try doing a preliminary comp of this vocal?” I had been in the room for all the vocal takes, heard the discussion about approach and vibe, even made the singers coffee the right way… why not? That evolved into being trusted with recording stuff in the second studio… we were always running behind, and having me chip away at guitar tracking or re-amping was really useful. Years of this and we were a well oiled machine. I’d get looped into pre-production phone calls and meetings, he would start asking my opinion on things.. drum sounds, microphone choices.

author: spiderplus1

author: LAPhill
content:
I don't know why I didn't think of this sooner, but the closest parallel to the seismic shift of AI might be samples, even more so than things like digital recording or Pro Tools. When Hans Zimmer recorded an orchestra and started writing music with a DAW and showing clients mockups, nothing was ever the same. For a long time (even now!) the pencil-and-paper people griped about how it wasn't real composition. Orchestras feared that they would all be replaced by computers. But ultimately, everyone had to come to terms with the new world order and adapt. There was a period in the mid-90s through mid-late 2000s where orchestral writing was reduced to nothing more than long notes and short notes. All of the nuance was gone, because the tech couldn't handle it yet and people blamed the tech. Many mourned the loss of true orchestral writing, yearning for a by-gone era. 

But eventually, people learned to harness these new tools and they met the technology on its own terms. People are doing wildly innovative things with samples now, we've moved completely past the era of "can I make a convincing clarinet come out of my keyboard?" Orchestras and live musicians have not been replaced. Sure, the process is different than it used to be, but that's how innovations work. All of us would be living very different lives without samples of drums, guitars, orchestras, synths, etc. There will be a generation coming up where AI is already a thing, they won't have ever lived in the before-times. Just like those here who've never cut to tape. It's okay.

author: BatMeckley
content: Take a breathe. Don’t respond to the band. Vent to your manager and friends. Have an outlet for your “fuck these useless fuckwits” that doesn’t involve the fuckwits. Then, and this is an important step, execute the note. With your full heart and skill. More times than I’d like to admit the stupid note from the person that doesn’t know what they’re talking about ended up actually being a net positive to the record. And when they’re right, let them know. Artists love that shit. Plus, it’s their record. If you haven’t convinced them that it’s better for your inclusion on it, you probably fucked up.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Got a call this week to save a track. Producer turned it in pretty half baked and didnt give the mixer any direction. The first time the artist heard it was first pass at mix, and he HATED it. 

Artist was SUPER uncomfortable about the whole thing, but didn’t trust the producer to get it done for a bunch of reasons. 

1) the producer rushed the vocal recording. Artists wanted more takes but basically got bullied out of the room. 
2) The artist wanted to be there for the comp at least, producer refused. As I said, first time he heard it was after first mix pass. 
3) producer baked some Sonics into the vocal that were very outside for the artist, and there were bad edits & poor Melodyne work to boot. 


Now not only is the mixer gonna have to mix the vocals all over again (we’re retracking,) but all the other shit I’m adding/changing. 

So this producer made the artist uncomfortable and then made more work for everyone, on a major label budget. 

I’m not gonna speculate on the why, but there are some lessons here.

author: tim adamson 🇦🇺
content:
I wanted to make a similar heartfelt post. I've been super under the pump the past few months with corporate AV work and had a last minute session yesterday that went really well and everyone's super happy with! 

This was only the second session I've done in this studio, the first was a semi nightmare which lay beyond my control (I had two hours to setup from scratch and record 4 tracks with a trio in a brand new room.. and I'm no Noah Needleman) although everyone's happy with it, it was somewhat disheartening to have my first session back in the studio be completely rushed and slapped together 

This time I really wanted to prepare and took to digging in the server for a game plan. Shout outs to @chrissorem and @Eric Martin, I picked up 2 x m88s for vocal and double bass.... I'm super impressed and stoked with how these sound and I wouldn't have found them without your suggestions. (I also got a great deal on a M130, I haven't heard many people talk about them but it ruled on overhead)

But mainly, as someone who's not recording everyday, after a pretty average session a few weeks back, just reading this servers helped really refresh my perspective on why I'm doing what I'm doing and to go into the next session better prepared and focused. Very nice to have great feeling tracks right after and pretty average session in a new space

Big thanks to everyone!!

author: Rollmottle
content: Great artists can become shitty artists. It takes work to stay great. Many artists become high on their own supply and think anything they do or say is good just by virtue of them doing it. Being a provocateur for the sake of provoking without much apparent rhyme or reason is…boring? not great? easy? cheap? Add unmanaged mental illness and endless money on top of it and you get Kanye. author: BatMeckley

author: thegreatcarsoni
content:
Awesome. I'm seeing this right now with a friend's band, so ima jump on the bandwagon here. I just took over mixing the album, which has been in progress for years. Everybody tells me the producer/band leader is this prolific asshole, constantly blowing up at people and impossible to please. The previous mixer had been mixing this thing for months/over a year and everyone was worn out/not getting results. I was really reluctant to take on the project for fear of being intimidated/failing to deliver.

I've made a point of greeting the producer at every step with clear communication, enthusiasm, and an open mind. I genuinely love the music and have made a point of letting him know how much fun it's been to work on the stuff. And, similar to your story, we were basically approved on the first track within 4 mixes and the guy seemed really really happy.

Everyone just said this guy was a hopeless asshole, but what I saw was a guy who was working so hard to bring a vision to life and just struggling to get there; self-financing, overseeing everything, etc... and it's fairly complex, hip hop and soul vibes with practically a full orchestra and 3 vocalists, so it's a lot to manage. Not trying to excuse the asshole behavior, but I see the frustration and I really wanted to highlight how much cool work he had done and that, without any fuss or needless back and forth, we would just get it where it needed to go. i tried to just think about how exciting it could be to finally hear these songs that've been bouncing around in his head actually come out of the speaker the way he imagined. We've got 7 songs almost done now and I've grown so much just from these attitude alignments i've picked up from spending time here.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I mean, I usually shoot for around -9LUFS. Depending on the track, I get there in different ways. (But the client never hears what I send to the ME.) Then I take off the last “make it loud” elements and send both hot and non-limited prints, so they can hear what the client approved after doing their thing. 
(Like doing measurements in your room after you get it feeling good.) 
Honestly this is mostly because certain elements behave differently when you start to squash a track. I wanna have a good guess for what’s gonna happen when Anthony smashes it through Waves L2 & send it back and charges me full price.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Another quick story, I was streaming a production/mix with my old boss / mentor / producer Jon Kaplan, thinking I was close and just wanting an outside ear. 

During the first chorus, Kaplan goes “solo the kit… flip the phase on the mono room and dip 400hz in that mic.”

He didn’t even ask if there *was* a mono room mic. 

And I kid you not, all the sudden the snare jumped like 4db in the mix. I muted the claps I was using to bolster 2 & 4 and the mix was done. 

That was one of the most virtuousic moments of listening I’ve ever witnesssed.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’m going on record to say I love the concept and physicality of vinyl, and how it requires you to actually take a breath, be careful with the needle, etc… but
I might be the only guy on the planet that prefers the sound of digital. I hate that vinyl requires sonic and artistic compromises to be made, like the fact that Peter Gabriel had to change the track listing of SO, because In Your Eyes couldn’t play properly on the inside of side two, so they had to make it the opening track of side two to properly handle the bass. 
I hate that I had to remix C’mon (and any other record I’ve done for sub pop) specifically for vinyl because it couldn’t handle the sheer majesty of my extended bandwidth. I call shenanigans on the whole empire.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
It sucks when someone comes down on you for anything tho. Like I am absolutely the hardest on myself, so anyone else tryna be hard on me feels immediately like piling on. Tough to hold your cool through that. 

When I worked at the Cheesecake Factory in my early 20s, the regional manager was a woman larger than the man who was the local gm, and whenever she came to town he’d get real meddlesome and annoying to his staff, making us all worried that somehow our normal workflow wasn’t good enough. It was bad vibes. 

But I’ll never forget a coworker coming over to me and saying, “can you imagine the two of them having sex?” And then walking away like servers do after dropping a one-liner at a table. 

I laughed, but honestly it changed my entire perspective on managers or bosses or anyone in authority. They’re just people, dealing with their own anxieties either heroically or poorly, and I can choose how much of that take on myself. And if I do choose to, I do it out of compassion, not fear. 

… I hope that makes sense.

author: BatMeckley
content:
This is such an unpopular take, but the people that I know that are truly great are making a living at it. Maybe not as much as they “should” (sometimes if I want to hate my life I imagine what my house would look like if the success I had was in the 80s and 90s and not the last 15 years) but again, it really does come to doing actually great work. “Work harder, suck less”. Ruqaurphï’s advice is really the best advice: focus, and bust ass. There’s a limited amount of slots out here of people that get to make a living out of what most do as a hobby; someone out there is willing to out hustle you and will lap you no matter how much of a head start being gifted gave you.

The other day I had brought up in the monitoring thread about how the quality of work has been diluted by how easy it is now to do adequate work. The “my cousin has a 5D, he can shoot your wedding for $50!” problem. Yet Glenn Luchford still gets 6 figures for photo shoots. Quality wins.

Yesterday I got to hang with Zack Cervini’s gf at a baby shower. Zack just bought a house. Cause he’s been kicking everyone’s ass at a certain genre of mixing and took his “internship to asst to fuck you pay me” mixer path seriously. There is still money to be made.

author: Chase H
content:
@franc.castillejos 
I’m in Milwaukee which is by no means an LA or a Nashville.

I’m getting closer to being able to go full time mixing and doing some recording/producing in this small town by honestly just going out to shows of artist I enjoy and networking with them on a personal level, not even bringing up me mixing or recording for them.

Fulltime will  mean different things to different people but to me that means being able to support myself, my future wife (I get married in May) and our future children being able to stay at home full time without my wife having to work.

I haven’t worked on anything big but I love Music and being able to be in service of someone else putting out their vision.

I was close to moving to Nashville last year as I have a good amount of connects but for my life it wasn’t the right thing,

This may not be worth much because I’m by no means a heavy hitter engineer like some of the people here but maybe it’s a good idea for you  to DEFINE what success is to you, and then work backwards from there.

Wherever you end up I’m sure there will be a community of artists that you gel with and over time can work with and help them present their art

author: Rob Domos
content:
The idea that the story we tell ourselves about the work is a distraction from the actual work applies as much outside of the studio as it does in. “What will XYZ person think about me because of the decision I make” is a pretty useless thought in terms of actually making the right decision. 

Adjacent thought; thinking about the preamp instead of about the song/performance is like thinking about your haircut while on a date. It’s so far outside of the bounds of what the moment is actually about that it’s comical. The above are all just pernicious ways of escaping the vulnerability required to show up in reality, when showing up is the whole task

author: cian riordan
content:
In the studio, this was like getting a golden ticket. It turns out, there’s no shortcut to greatness. You have to put in the work. Want to get a great drum sound? Do the work. Pick out the right drums. Spend time tuning them. Put them in the right place in the room. Try different places in the room. Try different drums. Setup some microphones. Listen. Adjust. Move the microphones. Maybe change the drums. Maybe change the microphones. Maybe they don't sound good because the part isn’t right? Maybe it's something else in the arrangement? Take it out. Try it. 

This takes quite a bit of motivation to get this deep in the weeds. But the results? Well, they were always unquestionably great. Could it have been fine with less work? Maybe. But you’d never know. And nobody is going to care about this record more than you are.

author: LAPhill
content:
To add on to the great advice being shared, keep in mind that the work of caring doesn't only happen when you're in the thick of it. If you get to the finish line and think "I wish that snare was punchier," or "We got there, but I'm not sure that mic was the best call in that situation," you can still experiment after the fact.

I've found that no matter how much time and effort I put in, when a project is over, there are new questions and things I want to try. So I might take a day a few weeks later, when it's slow, and shoot out some compressor plug-ins, or try to dial in a bass tone better than I achieved at the time. 

Figuring those things out when it's slow lets me be more efficient and focused when I'm head-down on a project.

The practice of mastering, the way I envision it, is fucking expensive and my day job allows me to do it the way I see it. That time seems to be about 10 years for most people to even get a real opportunity. And in the 10 years I’ve seen a LOT of talented people fall of the mountain.

author: BatMeckley
content:
This is a pretty good encapsulation of what I’ve tried to Mr Miyagi here in this discord since I’ve joined. Virtually all the people I know that have made it work in this business have THIS in common. They might not all be compression wizards, they might not all play an instrument… there’s so many things different about them… but THAT duality seems to be the common thread of everyone I know who makes it (which again, is why I posted that  Noel interview). I can argue passionately about the difference between mics or even converters, the specifics of Bluetooth latency, and also truly believe in “just get to work”. I can relentlessly take the piss out of Cian and deeply respect him as a person and his talent at the same time.

I’ll admit I sometimes get bummed when it seems that a couple people read it as “oh, the trick is to be rude about someone’s Nan”, and it’s like no, the trick is to take music seriously and treat it as the magic gift that it is, while not taking ourselves too seriously and sucking all of the magic out of it.

Noel seems to encapsulate that better than I am currently.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
Not sure how long you feel like you've been in this state, but it kinda sounds like you're describing the place just before it's your lyrics and arrangements on NMF. 

It's hard to draw parallels because I came up pre streaming and there's just a lot more people making records. But I had my first 3-4 things that started getting attention get taken away from me by managers/ labels/ bigger producers/ bigger mixers. Once I got to that next level it was obvious why I wasn't the guy yet. But if you're working on things that are at some point getting out there in a real way, that's the place that most people are before they jump up. 

Some of it is opportunity, some of it is skillset, some of it is time management (if you're hustling, it helps to turn great shit around before everyone else), and some of it is just the intangibles that come from more reps. 

My One Direction song came out 17 years after I first recorded the first band I was in. I'm not recommending anyone spend 17 years doing something all the time for no real money. But that's how it went for me.

Pick yourself up and just don’t make the same mistake again, or if it’s less specific, just /do better/. I try not to think too much about anything I wish I’d done differently in the past, and I think I do a pretty good job about it—and that affects my work in a very positive way because I am learning as I go, and just constantly improving and getting my ego out of the way of it. author: BatMeckley
content:
I mean… I guess it depends how you listen to music? There’s a lot of people that were like “Coldplay sounds like Radiohead!” Because it was a skinny British guy with falsetto, and in my opinion, those people were missing the point. If you’re a Radiohead fan, and/or a Coldplay fan you know how different they are at the things that truly make them them. 

Similarly with the Beatles/beach boys, if you’re understanding of it is “four freshmen style harmonies!” Yeah, they’re going to sound different. But, I was close with George Martin and Geoff Emerick, and very close to the Wilsons, and I can tell you they BOTH told me how hard they were chasing the ETHOS of each other, the experimentation, the pushing the boundaries of recording, the way the records made them FEEL. 

Going “Beatles didn’t have a single song about surfing” is missing the point in a Coldplay/radiohead way. In the ways that actually matter, they were strikingly similar

author: BatMeckley
content:
I’ve got a good one of these: a girl I worked with came by to record a feature on a DJ Duo’s song. We spend a day or two recording it, and it’s AMAZING. I bring by everyone I know by the studio to play it for them, because I KNOW it’s a hit, and i want to be the guy who called his shot. I’ve got points on it, and possibly even a piece of the publishing. 

A few months later my little brother calls me and says “hey, I just heard *artist B* singing that song you played me that had *artist A* on it.

That song became one of the most played songs of that year, now nearing 3.5 billion streams on Spotify alone. My cut would have easily been in the hundreds of thousands of dollars, if not breaking a million.

¯\_(ツ)_/¯ 

Sometimes the stuff we do pans out. Sometimes it doesn’t. We kick Cian in the ribs and we move on.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Pretty damn frequently. Producers moreso than mixers.

When I find a record that resonates with me I'm very full-immersion and I'll devour as much of their adjacent body of work as I can. I'll start scrutinizing the record credits and pulling on threads as I see them. I really try to fill in the context around the record by identifying all collaborators, timelines, interviews they gave around that time, published works, etc. I've got a huge appetite for that thing.

I really love reading books written by producers. The more old school the better. Phil Ramone's *Making Records* is a great one. That guy is a class act. Quincy Jones has both an autobiography *and* a book specifically on producing. The latter is a great no-shortcuts look at what it takes to be great. I enjoyed Daniel Lanois' *Soul Mining*, since he's got a very thoughtful immersive way of making records and working with artists that I appreciate.

author: peterlabberton
content: Just offering this as another perspective, but one that's more focused on engineering, not producing: I worked on *so* many lame ass records and projects that I'd never show anyone, but I saw every one as an opportunity to build my engineering chops on someone else's dime. This was mainly as a staff engineer at a big studio, which is its own hustle, but if you can look for something to learn/improve/gain on each project, I don't think every single session needs to be the most artistically/personally satisfying thing. Then you have this wealth of experience to take into the sessions that do really matter. You're sharpening your tools everyday if you can land a situation like that—AND if it's aligned with what you ultimately want to do.

author: oaklandmatt
content: So maybe you wanted to take it 90% toward what your ears want to hear, and instead, you're using a little soothe and getting at 15% closer. The artist is happy, and you've improved their work. If you get there, that's a win.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Man… this is something I wrestle with a LOT in todays climate of “send the artist home with a track! Send to the label halfway through the session!”, and honestly I just don’t do it anymore. Demo-itis such a real thing that everyone is convinced they don’t suffer from, and sending out something wrong but fast has ALWAYS fucked me in the end. I just do my best to gas light everyone into thinking it’s ok to give it a day and that perspective is one of our most powerful tools in making great music. Otherwise everyone gets hyped, listens to a song 38 times that night (to a track that won’t come out for 7 months) and convinces themselves that’s how it should sound and now comping etc become an uphill battle. I really really really hate the “this immediate comp sucks but its quick” mentality.

(This is not to be confused with tracking things quick and dirty to catch a vibe, which I’m very much for. Write drunk, edit sober)

author: Deleted User
content:
what are some things that you’ve been wanting to do outside of work life? 

I feel like the idea of “break” can look and feel different to many people, and I think the key is to find what version of those variations give you the most peace of mind and self acceptance. 

Personally, I have a few tendencies and mindsets around break that self-sabotages. things I listed below help me fight the self-sabotaging

1) going armadillo- when in extreme overwhelming state, you gotta find a way to get out of that. I get overwhelmed very easily, so I find that this is often needed. BUT, if you’re gonna go armadillo, then you wanna really commit to it until you feel a bit calmer and collected. Which leads to the next point 

2) sometimes I lie to myself that I’m taking a break but do a few spurts of work because I feel useless not doing work. I’ve learned that this needs to be avoided or else the “break” will be extended into a longer period of time, and I’d be doing little work here and there but also not get anything done properly. It takes a bit of commitment to take a proper break, and in order  to be able to commit to it - recognizing it as a part of maintenance routine to stay well functioning is really important in my experience. I am pretty bad at pacing myself and managing my own mental and physical wellness, so I am working towards being able to put the brake on early enough so that I don’t crash or skid away into a crash 😂

3) to deal with that feeling of feeling useless, I found that doing things that I wanted to do can help once I have gotten calmer by being in armadillo state for a bit. Getting straight back to work from here for me is extremely difficult, so I start with the combination of taking care of chores that got backed up from busy life and doing what I desire outside of work life. Could be trying a new restaurant, picking up a new hobby or getting back to the hobby that gone on hold due to work life

author: joshbonanno
content: i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face....wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great, because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist...or in some cases, even the intended audience. with that said...if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. / might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it...so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world...but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: Rob Domos
content:
Also think about turnaround times. You work on 15+ songs a day as an ME, you hear aberrant clicks and pops in *nearly every single one of them* 

With asking the person who sent you the files to do it, you spend your whole day emailing and managing files. It takes longer to open gmail than it does to zap the click. 

And think of the logical conclusion of asking the mixing engineer to fix the edit. They don’t have the edit, they have the comp. So then if you extend the logic they have to hit up the producer, and MAYBE the producer has to hit up the recording engineer if you really wanna “get to the source”. It’s like the meme of the producer who didn’t want to use splice because it was cheating and ended up farming sheep to get skin to make his own drumheads. Just do the fucking work. There’s no time to email back and forth about things that can be fixed immediately

author: montrose recording
content: hot take! id be thrilled if i had written golden age personally.  but on the sonics vs songs thing,  im usually alot more moved by how something makes me feel coming out the speakers vs the composition of lyrics, harmony, and melody.  for me, james brown is more emotive than james taylor.  sam cooke more emotive than stevie wonder.  madlib more emotive than nickelcreek.  sparklehorse more than john mayer.  tame more than bleachers.  i can see a thread between emotive ‘fixed format’ music like the blues and soul (say howlin wolf/ otis redding/stones) to hip hop/beat music/dance and effectively beck and tame.  i def feel a bit of a knee jerk reaction when someone says ‘this is song and this is definitely not song’ though.  like who is to say that campfire translation makes something more than how sex machine,  devils haircut or elephant make me feel.  just my 3 cents!

author: Chad Rodgers
content:
This is a great conversation and it’s super interesting to see how culture and geography influences it.

As a Brit, the class system very much underpins life, even now (but in much different, more complex ways), so I share some of @Deleted User’s sentiments as the game is often rigged against a large portion of the populace despite their best efforts to turn things around for themselves. If only we had pure meritocracy here. Sam Fender put it really well this week with regards to the music industry so I won’t go over stony ground, you can google his thoughts which I largely relate to.

As an individual I’m horribly determined and annoyingly persistent when I have a goal in mind, as well as always balancing that with being the kindest person I can be towards others (sometimes to my detriment) and pretty much always in a headspace of bettering myself personally and professionally. This has generally been the key to many of the opportunities I’ve been given. There’s an English word for it, “nous”, which I think is similar to agency but also encompasses the notion of having “good sense”. I quite like that as it’s less about intelligence, and more about personal character. Just my two cents. As always firing off quick thoughts in a session break so I’m sorry if my take is a bit disconnected.

author: cian riordan
content:
Simple answer, but probably the greatest thing I ever learned from EV is: "it's all about how much you care”. 

If any of you have spent time around him or seen his videos, it’s pretty clear that he goes deep on all of his productions… there’s no stone that’s left unturned, no excuse to not take it fully to the end zone. There were surely some parts of this that seemed exhausting during the record making process… it surely broke a lot of musicians sitting bored on the control room couch for weeks on weeks on weeks while he labored over their recordings.

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: My 2c: from August 2024 to October 2025 I worked with an artist where they brought me bones of songs and we co-wrote an albums worth of work together. They moved from the city to central massachusetts and while the songs and mixes are about 80% done, they can't get above water time and travel wise to finish the project and its put on hold for next year. This is a big record for me as a producer and musician, and it sucks that I put so much time and effort into it but in the end, I hope waiting it out  and getting back to refocus in 2026 will be worth it. On the other hand, I get hired by a band, they are super intense and ambitious about recording, mixing, and releasing - the album comes out and they breakup in 3 months or theres a lineup change where the new drummer has a home studio and can record everything there and mix it then 6 months later I get a IG dm to bail them out becuase the drummer fucked the guitarists wife and the bass player and vocalist are just going to finish the record on their own with me.

author: Berlin
content:
I found last year really focusing on a morning routine for myself (self care, if you will) helped me to stay positive. At least I am taking care of myself first and that is all something I can control. Then I can take on the variables and unknowns of the day. Makes for a late start for me now (to which, I'm still adjusting)... but I feel fully ready to face the day every day. Nothing in the back of my mind lingering, letting myself down.. 

Additionally I have let my self imposed work hours go, just freeing myself to be open to the art life as it comes, any hours of the day. Trying to bottle everything into a 9-5 was difficult for me.. why are artists calling me at 9pm? Well.. that's when they are off from their day job and can talk. I took that boundary away for myself and felt some self imposed frustration melt away. Grateful for the calls, emails, texts, DMs.. any hours. Bring it on. 

Both of these changes have helped my attitude and optimism AND HOPE of a future in music and art.. Continuing this on into 2026.

author: Slow Hand
content:
After a decade of performing, touring, and doing production work (and stressing about financial insecurity through much of it) I started an unrelated business with a partner four years ago.

This has turned out to be the right choice for me because it relieves the financial stresses and insecurities and (much like @kidcutler) it allows me to cherry pick the gigs that I want to do.

For a while, making a living on music was a point of pride (or shame when it was not going well). I've always felt a tension between the work that I wanted to create and it's commercial viability. So finding an alternate path to support myself has taken a huge cognitive load off of me and given me the independence to relax and (consequently) better fund my music ventures and enjoy the process again.

author: LAPhill
content: My advice: Get a mortgage payment that you can handle paying even if you go a few months without working, factor that into your calculation of how much house you can afford. And keep some money tucked away because things WILL come up that need to be fixed urgently from time to time. Going up to, or over, how much house you can afford will force you into taking jobs you don't want to take when things go even a little bit sideways.

author: oaklandmatt
Iwan Morgan
content: So, I teach part time at undergraduate level in the UK, and the main complaint most of my students that have come from earlier music tech education is that they have been told things, or lectured at passively but not been able to get their hands on the equipment or be in real or close to real experiences.  In my teaching I get them active early in the process.  Get them excited by the process, find out if there are any players in the group.  Get thme to jam, let the others engineer.  Rotate roles frequently.  Teach them fundamentals while they work.  Some people spend 3 hours teaching them how to coil a cable, and while this is important I always work it into a real environment.  Always, always ask what their favourite songs are and relate the teaching to that.  Got a room full of EDM kids? Get them to engineer a band tracking, then get them to deconstruct and remixit the next week using a DAW.  In doing this they'll learn far more and you can tailor specific elements as you go.

author: Rollmottle
content:
I've worked in digital automotive as a product designer for almost 10 years, both on the new and used side. 

1. Unlikely. Supply chain is still in shock from 2020. Probably won't fully be recovered for another 18-24 months.
2. Depends on the need. For a business, leasing probably makes more sense than owning. The lease can be taken as a deduction.
3. If you are buying new, you will eat the depreciation cost. If you are buying used, the depreciation is already priced in. If you want a relatively new car, I will always recommend going Certified Pre-Owned. One of the better deals in automotive with the benefit of a likely extended warranty coverage. There are plenty of high quality used vehicles out there that are effectively new (full disclosure, I work for Carvana...the vehicles are reconditioned similar to CPO standard). My last I don't know how many cars have all been gently used late-model used cars. Cars these days are more durable and reliable than they've ever been. Low risk in buying late-model used. I will only ever buy used anymore.
4. Whoever offers you the lowest APR. That is often the captive lender, but rates are a bit of a cluster fuck these days so shop around for the lowest. One fun fact: if you are buying from a dealer, APR's are negotiable. They will tell you that's the best they can do, but they take margin on the loan. There's meat on the bone there if you want to do battle. 
5. Car prices can fluctuate seasonally yes, but wouldn't try and time the market. You won't save that much.

author: jantrit
content:
I’m going  fail to properly put this into words but the ability to extrapolate and have an understanding of the learning process/ be driven to take that journey. One example would be this, someone comes in fresh expecting you to spoon feed them the knowledge, that’s not super helpful. But someone comes in and can say, “oh that’s a Patchbay, can you show me how it works”. You can teach those people anything. The desire and hunger to learn on their own and the ability to acquire knowledge for themselves has been a huge divide I’ve noticed in the intern/ college community.  

One time we were setting up a session and I was explaining to our intern my thoughts about which headphones we’d give to each station. (This pair has better bass, we’ll give them to the bass player. These are open back we’ll give them to the horn section so they can blend better) The very next session without having to mention it, she had placed the same headphones in the same places AND ALSO she then took that info and made a the judgement that we’d give the nicest most comfy pair to the vocalist. That’s what I mean about extrapolation.

author: Deleted User
content:
So I wanted to take some time to write this down and share it with you guys. I recently watched Jeff Ellis talk about his mixer brain concept and it really clicked for me this time. I think it ties in a lot with what’s being discussed on here and what I think even was the main theme to the conversations podcast. It’s about Regaining the Connection to your Senses. 

For a long time now I was living in a kinda “numb” state where everything I listened to, looked at, tasted, touched and smelled was “overruled” by my rationality (what I would describe as a sixth sense). So I was constantly living in this thing where my rationality dictated my connection to my surroundings, which lead me to be in a very anxious, depressed kind of state obviously reflecting back at my work. 

Now with that realisation I started practicing focusing on just on sense at a time, like putting my visual sense in the foreground or just deeply listening and so on. It immediately set back the rationality sense in a way, where it would leave the space to really experience the emotion of the stimulus. 

It really feels great and I want to take a moment to really thank everyone on here for leading the conversation to a better place. Big love for you guys ❤️

author: Rob Domos
content:
I have a scalding hot take that the “indie girl” voice isn’t a fad and came about because it’s the optimal way to sing for the medium. 

Think of how opera doesn’t sound like human speech. That alien sound came about because extremely loose muscles create far less sympathetic intermodulation which sounds cleaner. It’s the same as how a speaker makes your desk vibrate and create out of time interference pattern distortions. Muscle tension creates hard surfaces that do the same when singing and opera singers obsess over undoing this. This is a big reason why so many of your favorite vocalists are opioid and benzo addicts. It’s not just culture. Downers are performance enhancing here. (Please don’t get any ideas artists) 

The modern pop voice is just maintaining that exaggerated opera looseness but with adaptations for the modern medium: English diphthongs instead of Latin ones, way less air in their lungs because the target is a foot from their mouth instead of 50 feet, and softened fricatives because a capsule right in front of the mouth harshly exaggerates fricatives. 

From a physics perspective it’s the perfectly optimized way to sing in 2024. You may not like it, but this is what peak performance sounds like

content: Being a voice actor, I'm expected to travel with recording equipment and make sessions happen during whatever trip i take, as I'm sure many of you working music folks do. Found myself going "what time is it?" and then had to tell myself "eh...it doesn't really matter" and that was a great feeling that took some getting used to. I definitely feel different coming back from the trip, and it's more important to me now that i'm back in my work environment that I make a more conscious effort to create space for me to be the person i want to be, and not the person that everyone wants me to be "on demand" and a deadline.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
@spectrummasters 

No surprise Ross with an extremely thoughtful post and approach, and you always with a very thoughtful initial question.

Gonna keep this as short as possible since it’s late, and I guess I’d sorta like to ruffle a few feathers lovingly. 

But from the freelance/work for hire side that I’m on, and most of us here are, I have to say, most people out here doing the thing are getting paid their ACTUAL value. 

Yet everyone thinks they are worth more. Why? Who cares that we work hard? Not the market. We make art that is totally non-essential to how society operates…for most of the projects we touch there is almost no demand and they will make very little money. Of course this doesn’t mean they are not important, I deeply think they are, but we are talking financial value here.

We need to either provide people with an amazing experience (in many ways) that they find valuable or help them earn more money. Ideally both

If you are undeniable and continue helping people earn more, feel more, be more, create more…the money cannot help but follow. And the market will tell you your value whether you like it or not

I don’t say this with the experience that others do, I have a long long way to go. so know that and of course take into account my perspective. This is all from a very loving place!

author: spectrummasters
content: Coming back on this ,bit corny but this is my testament to the value of rap. I’ve taken the summer to work back on a construction site to get away from screens and endless inside days , get some vitamin d and all that . There’s this kid who is on as a labourer . He’s just pushing dust around all day with a broom and carrying whatever crap the supervisors tell him to move  just to keep him busy . He found out I mix and produce and has been sending me his songs and is waiting for me to give him the nod and set up a tracking session . He’s pretty good and really young . Maybe he could be something . Dunno . But I do know when I walk past him on site looking bored as fuck and wondering why he’s even here …..he’s just writing bars in his head , cause he spits them to me when we are done and all heading home . This sounds corny but it’s so weird being an engineer and having all the skill and gear required to turn someone’s vision into a reality . In the world of music you become their best friend and confidante . Those threesome stories lol , sometimes they get replaced with something deeper …..stories about absent parents and betrayals by friends and lovers . These things are rarely discussed between men here , vulnerability is a weakness …..so it’s crazy how many times I’ve been tracking and thought ……damn this is deep, im a part of a therapeutic process . Or just some made up shit about menages 😂. I will record this kid though . He needs it

If anyone wants to chime in with ideas, I’m thinking of offering a free session to students at my university to come record with me/just letting friends I trust into my spaces to use while I’m in class or whatever

author: Slow Hand
content:
I think a good way to summarize the benefit of Andrej's approach here is by looking at two different ways to go about learning how a frog works: 

1) You can dissect a frog to learn about it. You observe the long legs, the muscles, the skin, the eyes, the respiratory system, etc. You see it's strengths and you see it's weaknesses and you draw your conclusions from there. This would be the top-down learning approach. It's good at describing what already *is*. 

Or...

2) You build/design a frog from scratch. You will quickly come to understand why things *have* to be the way they are. You realize that all of the evolutionary "choices" about a frog's physiology are simply the best possible compromises, given the pressures of the environment, the availability of resources, and the limits of physics. By building it yourself you will come to perceive all of the invisible challenges and "solved" problems that were required to make an organism that will simply survive, much less thrive.

This firsthand experience of building the thing will actually make you an expert because you've done the hard work and experienced it for yourself. You took ten paths to failure and made every mistake before settling on a a non-obvious compromise that allows you to balance it against every other factor. You understand *why* it needs to be that way.

This knowledge will make you robust and flexible, whereas top-down knowledge is more superficial and brittle. If the conditions of your subject change and the model you understand is no longer relevant then you're in a far more precarious place than someone who's built something from the ground up.

author: cian riordan
content: Sonic consistency amongst songs on a record is one of those things that gets harder as you move further through the production processes. In an ideal world, you'd map out an aesthetic for a record in pre-production and make choices in recording & production to try and stay within those lines, whatever that means. A real world example I have is when I was doing the last Mini Mansions album, we locked onto a few H3000 patches that sort of defined how the drums and ambience would sound throughout the record. We obviously didn't use it on everything, but it helped thread the needle through a wildly diverse batch of songs. After that, having one person mix the whole album will undoubtedly help tie together a record that's been all over the map in production -- be it different styles or producers. As someone that often is tasked with doing this, I am always referencing other songs in the album to try and make sure things are sounding 'consistent'. By the time mastering comes, everything should sound 99% complete.

content:
Stereo. I tried out some Atmos headphone mixes at an Apple store kiosk a while ago because I was curious. I can't say that it had much of an effect on me. Maybe I need to live with them for longer and get used to it.

Last week was the first time that I was able to sit in front of an Atmos setup that was meant for music (aka: not in a movie theater) and really get the full musical experience. In fact, I got to sit in front of *three* different Atmos rigs in three different (treated) rooms that evening and two of them were undoubtedly set up as good as they could have possibly been (One was a PMC showroom and the other built and tuned with their input). While the speakers themselves were impressive and very capable, the actual experience felt pretty disjointed. There was a pronounced feeling of phasi-ness that I didn't like.

It was great hearing these records on a rig that probably cost $250k, but my big takeaway was that they felt disjointed and odd. Even when sitting in the sweet spot.

Perhaps my opinion will change with more exposure, but I'm not yet convinced that it's worth the time and effort. I will add, though, that half the mixes we heard were up-mixed from old stereo recordings with minimal track counts and only two of them were modern productions.
