author: Rollmottle
content: haha...I'm a UX designer by trade and would have approached this problem differently. i don't know that we actually have a problem where we need a more structured and rigid way of soliciting feedback on music. maybe in certain high volume scenarios, i can see the use case. for mixing and mastering, putting an interface in front of somebody that makes a user think "oh shit, i can comment down to the every last second!" seems ripe for 1. woodshedding and focusing on things that in any other listening context wouldn't matter 2. makes me think I *have* to say something. as my client, i'd much rather you take the music wherever you feel most comfortable in whatever way you want to consume and just listen and then communicate back to me however you'd like without the pressure of a UI that might be unnatural to that workflow in front of you. it's a philosophical thing i suppose...i never want to add friction to your natural way of thinking about something, especially your own music.

author: itaylerner
content: I don’t think it’s a way back, I think it’s a way forward to a new future. Music has been around longer than language, it’s not going anywhere. It’s human. But, this is late stage capitalism, and the internet / flattening of accessibility is probably the biggest immediate shift in human history. This world is all still VERY new and it will take time for us to learn what we’re doing and adjust accordingly. I don’t have any idea what it’ll look like, and I tend to get cynical when I spend too much time zooming out. There are times where it’s productive to intellectualize the landscape and try to understand things, but we can’t see the future, and that’s ok. The weight of this isn’t on us as individuals, it’s on everyone. So i just try to zoom in, make great art, do good, fair business, and do my part to contribute at each step of the way. Not really an answer to your question but I think about this ~a lot~ and this is the healthiest way for me to think about it without going crazy haha.

author: Barbara
content:
I have to let you know my first experience with this. Been working on an album that I recorded one year ago. Recording took us 7 days and they still needed to add synths and bass fot some of the songs after that (side note: the production wasn't finished by the time we tracked, so I edited everything I had - 10 songs, none of them with less than 5 minutes. It was the band's first time in the studio, also, and had to edit lots of drums and bass stuff). After doing a first pass, I sent them the multitracks they asked for, to track the rest of their stuff with their producer (a colleague of mine). The next 8 months were spent waiting on their files to start mixing (this was supposed to last 1/2 months, max). When I finally got the files, you have no ideia how messy the project turned out (track names, bounce mistakes, ultrapocessed tracks with artifacts - even the ones we've tracked at the studio before, audible edit points,... all you can imagine going wrong at this point), so it took me a bunch of time to organize everything in a way that I could work with what I've got (going back and forth asking the producer for some files that didn't even get to me or asking if there was the possibility to get some of the tracks dry, without processing or fx - keep this in mind).

Needless to say, when I was ready to start mixing, I was already overwhelmed and tired of it, and I knew I still had a long way to go...

First version took me probably too long to get right (2 months, approx., working on other projects that got scheduled on those 8 months) and I've sent it before I went on a few days vacation.

author: popaganda.
content: My understanding of India in general is that there’s a lot of societal and social pressure to have everything figured out and be on your perfect life path by a certain age, but that is kind of at odds with doing music which can be a winding road without life security built in. Maybe it’s harder to find people who are okay with the uncertainty of the life path you’re choosing. I would just say don’t buy into the pressure to have it all figured out right now and trust that there is a person out there for you who will understand what you do and love you for it. Unfortunately a lot of people do like to take advantage of us for various reasons, but I bet you can tell if someone is genuinely into you for you or if they’re trying to use you. You may fuck up a few times. That’s okay. It’s all experience that you’ll grow from.

author: Slow Hand
content:
I've never considered myself someone who's had substance issues of any kind (thankfully). I'm approaching the end of a self-imposed 3 month break from alcohol and as I near the finish line I don't feel as if I'm in any hurry to return to where I was.

I've been a casual drinker for over 15 years and recently have found that even 1-2 drinks the night before were leaving me feeling like shit in the morning, so I opted to remove them from the equation and see how I felt after my trial period.

No surprise, but it's been a positive one. I'll still drink on occasion, but it feels great not defaulting to that habit. It's probably been the confluence of several factors in my life, but right now I feel as good as I've ever been. I feel present and in-tune with the world around me and I think I'd be far less effective if I hadn't taken this break.

author: Rollmottle
content:
Letting yourself unplug and giving yourself the grace to do it guilt-free takes practice. This is something that has continually dogged me throughout my life. My problem solving brain is always on and it's hard to turn it off. It's really easy to fall into one's work and feel guilty or bad when you're not working even though you should be or have to be. Gotta just accept and walk away and not beat yourself up for needing to be unproductive. The bigger picture frame is a day or 3 or 10 of doing "nothing" is going to be a bigger payoff in the long run than in the short term trying to superhero through it half-in and potentially doing shitty work which could have compounding unintended long-term effects. 

Get high, have a drink, go for a walk, get out of town, watch a show, cook a meal...do nothing.

author: chadwahlbrink
content:
I often use the proMB freeband mode as a basic “denoiser” for high end. 

If I get a vocal with some schmutzy noise, I will dip the high end, but have the lower vocal fundamentals trigger expansion back to a “flat” frequency whenever the vocal is actually singing. Release time to taste from there.

Can also help with an over resonant drum or lower “hum” issue where you want to dip most of the time, but then have it be “flat” whenever the snare hits, or whatever.

Comes in handy for post work too. Cleaned up a lot of VO’s and SFX recordings with those methods.

author: sethearnest
content:
Does a balance need to be struck? Tell the truth of the situation -- a given person's motivation/confidence being or not being undermined will persist either direction over time. They'll soon enough meet the wall of Reality into which every one of us is continually smashed. And their intrinsic level of motivation/confidence will handle it or it won't. 

You tell a 12yo talented niece she can't be a professional singer, and she'll internally respond with either, "Oh...that's sad...I would've loved to do that," or she'll respond with some variation of "Efffffff that...I'm gonna' change the world," and then she might. 99% won't, but that attitude is table stakes for that 1% that we're all shooting for here. 

The latter response will happen no matter *what* is told to a given person with a high level of self-motivation. Giving the truth of the difficulties seems to only help by giving the motivated person more navigational wisdom.

author: spectrummasters
content:
I alternate between phases of 7am - 6pm construction work . V rigid schedule with v . Structured reliable pay. This is easy for my family life (good pay , evenings and weekends free ) 
…..and then an extended phase of writing , recording and mixing folks I work with . 
This phase always feels slightly slacker to me , I know it isn’t but hard to shake off . It comes from not being on a firms payroll with no fixed schedule nor income . Have four young children and a music lawyer Mrs so my dependants and my other half do weigh on my mind when I’m doing creative me . 
I will say a couple years ago I lost a hard drive of projects I’d written and produced over a year . During that year I’d spent hours away from my newborn and my other children recording and pouring everything into the work . Once it all disappeared into the digital ether the only thing I really missed was the time I’d not spent with my children , not the lost projects . Defo shaped my perspective moving forwards . I see being creative as essential but not the ultimate priority now and I think that’s good for my fam

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Real, potentially ridiculous, question : 

Does anyone else ever sit at their studio for the first time each day and feel like you’re doing a launch sequence for a takeoff and excited for the day of operating your very customized audio rocket to da moon?

Some days I just feel ready to lock-in and pilot my ship, no matter the circumstances, and those are the fun days that make the rest of musician life worth it.

I feel like this must be my version of an experience that we all have. We all definitely have ‘locking-in’ feelings; Where you’re going from ‘life’ to a place where you’re in control (DAWs/Instruments/Writing Pad).

Sometimes mines accompanied by the fantastical. The escape from mundane, where I’m sometimes a Rocketeer, other times a gladiator, other times a grown Man - It always changes through life, and I hope my experience resonates with some people who read this.

I came to realize I do this today, and it feels like a special and powerful moment for me, and if anyone relates, I’d love to know why.

author: hyanrarvey
content:
Yo speaking on what @Nomograph Mastering said a few days about staying cool…we have a producer in and so the whole room is a giant mess (like most studios are when they are locked out) and we sold an amp and we wanted to make profiles/name of it before it went out the door 

So the patchbay is a huge mess and I hooked up all the routing and wasn’t getting signal and I started to lose my cool and got super frustrated, Rick calmed me down and we worked out what problem was (I forgot I was feeding the the amp from the di multed on the patchbay instead of feeding it from the converter to run tones..) and after I got cooled down it clicked on why I wasnmt getting signal.



It’s extremely difficult to not get frustrated when trouble shooting and not get overwhelmed by a full patchbay but if you just take a second and breathe/calm down and start reversing your signal flow you’ll find the culprit and move on




Long story short as an engineer you gotta be the calmest one in the room

author: cian riordan
content: Nail on the head. I think I had mentioned this in a previous post, but these days notes tend to come in real time -- via text messages, dropbox comments, or sometimes even thoughtful emails. I'll usually take a quick glance, but then dump everything into a note file so I have everything in one place when I sit to do the revision. This can be useful when you'll get a thread of notes like 1) I'm not sure about the drum sound, it feel so x... then 2) someone else will chime in saying I love the drums! I think x is the problem then 3) first person is hesitant and shrugs of their not, even though it may still bother them. That way I can try and string together some sort of move that will hopefully make everyone happy. If you're dealing with a band -- and you're producing/engineering -- you'll have had the benefit of seeing the dynamic. Sometimes you get some people that are more engaged and tweaky, others that are unsure of EVERYTHING, and then people that when they say something, they're usually right, as infrequent as that may be. This is very useful during mix notes time because you have context. If you're just getting flies flown to you and you've never met the band/artist, thats certainly a bit more of a challenge and will likely require more work on your end to smooth things out.

author: peterlabberton
content: Thinking about numbers, i.e. a 2 db boost vs 4 db, and then endlessly ABing/being conservative with moves to a fault. At my old staff engineer gig I got to assist Joe Chiccarelli on a handful of tracking/mixing sessions. The most eye opening was assisting him mixing the latest Hellogoodbye record. He’d mix 2 songs a day on average, and just breeze through cranking on the 550 eqs in the console—not a care in the world what the numbers said. I’d take recall notes and print stems/various mixes and he and the band would go have lunch/dinner. Seeing him repeatedly just crank on shit until it sounded compelling was huge. Obviously, you need to have developed the instincts to do that tastefully and have it sound great, but that sent me down a path of being fearless and trying to not get hung up on looking at shit.

author: Slow Hand
content: Haha yeah. Reminds me of a story from the lapsteel player on Dylan's *Blood On the Tracks*. He was all by himself in this huge tracking room overdubbing lapsteel. After a few takes there'd be a pause while he waited for judgement from the control room. Eventually Dylan stepped out into the live room and got right up into the guy's face and said something really condescending to him about when to play. As Dylan turned away the guy describes having "nothing but contempt for Dylan in that moment" and he got super defiant and went into "Fuck you, Dylan" mode on the next take. Once the take was done he was left in silence to wonder. And as he squinted into the control room he could see everyone laughing their asses off. Apparently the whole think was a ruse by the control room to get a certain performance out of him.

author: Rollmottle
content: I'd pick one path and roll with it. As somebody's who's been at this crossroads (mixing & mastering vs. one or the other), I realized that to do one or the other the way I wanted to and do it right, I'd have to commit to one. And each of those paths imply different studio set ups and ergonomics and mindsets. I had 2 paths, you have 3. That’s a lot to ask of 1 space IMO. I don’t know how I could pull all of those disciplines off in the same space without feeling like I’m making a compromise somewhere. Tracking and mixing seem most compatible from a "one space" perspective. I bet focusing on tracking and mixing will be a relief and pay dividends for you. Your knowledge having done mastering before will be an asset to you in the tracking and mixing phase and make your end product even better.

author: ALXCPH
content:
I Think people lift their noses at shows like these, not to look Down on contestants. But more so the premis of the show.  The over production, the false reactions, the comments from the hosts/judges. The whole over-dramatisation that a lot of us can see right through. Also the fact that it is a contest because of “music ain’t a contest dude, it’s art✌️”. 

I think that the comparison to McDonalds is good, not because it is fast food or “low quality” or whatever, but because it’s not a food business. It’s a real estate business that uses food as a by-product(you know what I mean). These programs are just “reality” shows using music as a by product.

Sure there are some good meals, but I’m sure some chefs would up their nose at people who think McDonald’s defines the culinary experience as a whole. The same way a lot of Music people May feel misinterpreted by people who’s only intake of music is through these programs. 


Sorry rant over, was just a long stream of thought that came as I wrote it 😅 

My fave to come out of one of those programs is probably Harry Styles. He keeps impressing the further he goes in his career! 😇

author: LAPhill
content:
I would actually challenge you on this, unless I'm not understanding your point. The age of streaming has made new music compete directly with everything that came before it on equal ground. Maybe the context of it being "old" is somewhat lost, but that means the music exists on its own merits. Remember when Fleetwood Mac was topping charts again because kids were discovering it on TikTok? 

If anything, when new music comes in that's a take on something old, it better have something new to say - otherwise we can just click over to the thing it's aspiring to be.

author: LAPhill
content:
I'd argue that the best any of us can do is try to create work that we're proud of, at the highest level we can. It doesn't serve me to try to analyze what I'm working on through the lens of "is this undeniable?" 

My worry is that in the search for undeniable, we think it's okay to slouch and spend less time on something that we don't think has "it." But maybe my contribution will take something from great to undeniable. Or maybe the way I talk about it will inspire the next person down the line to push it over that line. Or maybe I can't see it because I'm too busy thinking about my mortgage payment or the questionable burrito I had for lunch.

Standards are great to the extent that it's a "north star" (I forget who used that phrase the other day, but feels appropriate), but if we're lucky, we'll work on a few undeniable things in our lives. The rest of the time, we still need to bring our best efforts and do great work.

author: Slow Hand
content:
American patriotism takes a lot of different forms. There is a certain amount of pride about the country that I find to well-earned and genuinely proud about. But depending on your social circles you're just as likely to find some people who take it way too far, and that's something that leaves a bad taste in my mouth. It gets pretty chauvinistic.

Patriotic rhetoric ends up being a lever used by politicians and adjacent political influencers to rally people to their causes (no surprise there), but lately it's mutated into a particularly ugly form and now there's a stark divide between people who have been radicalized towards extreme political positions and those who would reject them. One group unite under this brand of souped-up patriotism and the other tends to reject patriotic displays entirely because it resembles the first group.

No doubt you can find this behavior in lots of places around the world, but America's been feeling extremely polarized lately and overt national pride ends up being a symbol that's been co-opted by one group. So people here can be squeamish about it.

You'll likely be fine if you want to fly your American flag proudly. I don't want to dissuade you. Only highlight a little of our cultural baggage around that topic.

I apologize, I made a mistake in my previous answer. The XLR connector is not necessarily named after the "eXternal Line Return" acronym. The origin of the name "XLR" is not clear and there are several theories about its meaning. Some people believe it stands for "X" connector, others believe it stands for "Cannon XLR" or "Circular XLR." However, the name has become synonymous with a type of professional audio connector and is widely used to describe the type of connector regardless of the manufacturer.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Imma take a different tack on this. 

My advice would would be - DON’T. 

First of all, as an engineer, “giving” ideas to the vocalist is not your job. I get wanting to be apart of the creative process, but your part is to capture, not to impose. 

Secondly, the minute you start focusing on vocal techniques, its gonna distract you from the things that actually matter. Things like vibe and being a good hang. 

Third: singing ideas *at* a vocalist is not nearly as effective as you might think. However good a singer you are, when you sing an idea they’re going to hear so much more than you intend, and will likely mimic things you’re not trying to convey. It can be more detrimental than you’d think. 

All that said- focus on learning each artist individually, create an environment of trust and respect, and when the time is right, you’ll know how  to offer insight. But not if you’re trying to from the get go.

Catching up here, not sure how relevant but my best friend runs a very successful video business he built from scratch, is a mentor in a way (though he knows 0 about music).

One of his most enduring quotes to me is: “What you’re getting paid today is for your work a year ago (or x years, it can work for any duration)”

Essentially, crush everything in front of you and the money/growth will come with time, it takes time to catch up. Then again, the age old Ruairi-ism of thinking about the ambition matters too. Mine is almost maximally high, it is how I am. Someone who wants to make a comfortable living and work on records every day would maybe make very different moves or sacrifices based on this (neither is right or wrong)

author: shaunobi
content: Tbh… I have lots of keyboards, mostly mechanical, some rather expensive. I pull the key caps and throw them in denture cleaner overnight. Works wonders. I take the board itself and run it through the dishwasher (really). I leave it over the heater vent for a day so I know thing is dry as a bone inside, and plug ‘er back in.  Never had an issue. (And I’ve done this with multiples of my favorite IBM 3151 buckling spring keyboards from the 80’s, which are worth something, down to Dell Quietkey membrane keyboards, which are worth nothing but are nice)

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
Yeah for sure! Sounds like you're on a good path!! Totally understand the hesitation to delegate - especially that first 6 months-a year where you're acutely aware that helping someone else do it is *more work* than just rolling up your sleeves and doing it yourself. 

For building systems, what's worked for me is hiring and training your 'double(s)' first - someone with a similar skillset and sensibilities, very broad skills like me (who also did everything myself for a long time). This comes a lot easier if you have close friends in the same lane looking for jobs, I've seen people have their "double(s)" move in with them for a limited time too, with the intention of them soaking in exactly all you do.

Once my double(s) started doing pretty well, we started hiring more specialized people, and the doubles could then oversee their work, feedback etc - early on I would always be part of this, then slowly phase myself out.

What I wish I would have done earlier would have been to hire a producer/overseer/manager/'my boss' - someone with a bit more skin in the game/responsibility, and who keeps you in line if you start wavering. 

Again, I didn't love the setup of 10 and dissolved it eventually - as a creative it's easy to feel like you built a house/efficiency machine and one day you wake up and it's a prison that's not as flexible as you want. That's another thing I'm trying to keep in mind (I'm putting together a new similar team for this fall) - how do you keep the team agile and ready to shift when priorities shift? It could be as easy as accepting a little bit more churn & letting people go when they don't fit what's going on, but it's hard to let go of people you've trained and know well. I felt a friendship connection with my entire team, in hindsight I think that was a mistake too.

Those are some thoughts haha - what have you found so far? Are you experiences lining up with mine? What kind of roles are you hiring for?

author: masteredbyjack

Also read and enjoyed it, though I wish it were a bit longer/deeper on a few topics. I personally liked that Jon was honest about how he had a rough year -- I think the environment we live in online and in the engineer community very much rewards and expects a I'M DOING GREAT LOOK EVERYONE LOVES ALL MY WORK LIFE IS GOING ACCORDING TO PLAN type vibe. author: spectrummasters
content:
“I may never be able to grasp certain things “ / mystery . Love this man . This is it right here imho . Since primordial times we ve been staring into the great unknown . My friends and I got really into the beat poets , Ken Kesey ,aldous Huxley, Joseph Campbell  etc in our teens , going to school near Glastonbury and Stonehenge . There’s tons of ancient English mystical stuff down there . I take the view that we are the universe investigating itself . Probably just a “microorganism “ of a much bigger conceptual realm that we can catch glimpses of but not rationalise . I think Donald Hoffman has the closest view to mine I’ve heard articulated thus far . 

I like your fruit bowl analogy because it minds me of Picasso and Dali and how they’d render the bowl . 
When I was a lifeguard we had sessions for autistic children with high support needs , and the children would be reacting to stimuli that I could not “see “ . They’d be speaking to people or getting a scare from something I couldn’t see . I never once thought that they’re seeing things that aren’t there …..imho they are seeing things through a different filter to me .

author: Zack Hames
content: If the alternative is to back home, I’ll try to offer some advice from personal experience. I moved to Richmond, VA for a year, got a job at a hotel doing audio visual. I quit my first commercial/post production gig doing ads full time. It was the worst but I was determined to keep working in music, and try to get integrated in the scene/studio world. It was a serious low for my mental health, the job was terrible, I was struggling and scraping by without any pay off. To make a long story short, I applied for a job back home at a big corporate company with a full time composition/post production gig, on a whim - I didn’t think it would get me anywhere. 3 months later I got the job and went back home after a year. I was out of the music scene back home at this point, and it took another year of reconnecting and working hard on my craft with friends who were willing to let me record their bands for the price  of drums heads and guitar strings, and honestly, those two things combined with some luck put me in a very secure and creative place, now making records for bands again that are paying decently well to boot. I don’t know how far you are in your career/journey, but I’m barely anything and have been recording for 15 years. It took me 5 years out of school to get barely a living wage and working lots of different types of audio jobs while making records, to get to a comfortable place emotionally, creatively, and financially. I’d bet almost anybody in this discord has a very similar story. It takes a long time and like others have said, there’s no one way to get there. Just keep doing you and trying to work on things that you enjoy.

author: Rollmottle
content: I've been a software designer for almost 25 years and still do it. Been running a label, making/releasing music and doing mixing and mastering for that whole time as well. About 3 years ago it clicked that mastering is my thing and decided to spend the last few years dialing in my rig and room around mastering. The job has been able to subsidize what has turned into a parallel career. I have designs on having this be my full time gig at some point, but I'm taking it slow, honing my craft and building my client base and studio while the steady paycheck is there. It's nice to be able to do that without grinding to make ends meet. I realize that is a privileged position to be in so I am grateful. With COVID, I can also crank out masters while I WFH when there's downtime or I need a work break. Some weeks are harder than others from a workload standpoint, but mastering is part of my brain-therapy so I'm happy to take it all on.

author: cian riordan
content: Did this for years when everyone had tower Mac Pros... just slide in my drive and easy peasy. Then when I got the trashcan I would just tote that around and plug in. Now laptops are so fast that you could just plug in that way. Trying to navigate software versions and licenses -- not to mention linking sample libraries --  on someone else's machine is a nightmare. Bringing your computer is always the easiest way. If you're in Pro Tools, do yourself a favor and export the studios I/O settings into a file before you power down and swap over. That's my hot take.

author: Zack Hames
content:
I went to help a fellow engineer buddy record some drums today at his studio, and it made me think of something Jon Castelli said on the Conversations or LWMR podcast - he challenged the idea of being out of your comfort zone to grow, and look at the Benefits of the comfort zone.

My buddy is a great engineer and great drummer in a great and, so all great things. But his setup was just incredibly different than mine; he uses Studio One, I use pro tools (he’s also used to Pro tools and recently bailed on it). He’s using a combo of Antelope Discrete 8 and an Audient ASP880 and some good outboard pres (Vintech and Summit audio). His monitoring killed me, some small dynaudios which sounded okay and some ProAc’s. He had some decent mics. I brought my 8 Channels of UTA and a bunch of mics and was there just to put our heads together, and I was going mostly press record so he could drum for his bands record.

Anyway, we spent about 4+ hours trouble shooting Studio One, his computer, and the interfaces -eventually finding out one of his AD/DA channels was so messed up it sounded like a ribbon mic when it was a condenser. A lot of his mic stands and cables were really junky - he didn’t have enough of the basics on his own.

So many things were just not working as I would expect - my UTA preamps were set at much lower gains than I do at my studio because of his gear. I’m basically ear-blind because of the monitoring, even with headphones, and I’m working in Studio One so I can barely focus on the sound. And he used a normal Apple mouse, I use a trackball. 

Im trying not to complain, but it just blew my mind how much of an uphill battle recording can be just because of simple things being so taxing. We spent about an hour of the 6 hours I was there tracking one song. The rest was setup. It made me realize why we put so much work into making our process simple and getting gear that is effective and reliable.

author: Zack Hames

That’s rough. Sometimes offering a replacement can help. You know, hey I can’t take this any for X Y or Z, this person has help you finish this out if you want. 

Depending on your relationship, you could also just be brutally honest. Sometimes it’s a learning experience for them that they need.

Also what a bummer that tuning would take that long. A few hours redoing it vs months of back and forth seems like it should be obvious alternative but not every project has that luxury.

author: Deleted User
content: In the Bay Area here and have worked another job since Covid. It’s honestly a dream gig when it comes to production and music. It’s completely remote, no set hours, salary/insurance, and I use Pro Tools for the gig so it’s not completely foreign territory. Every remote gig is different and I realize this situation is a lot of luck and circumstance. Don’t be discouraged to take another gig. I was able to pay off high interest cards and can comfortably afford gear when I want it. I was full time in the studio from age 14-31 no other job. It was a transition, but one I’m glad I made. I’m still working mixing full time as well. I do production if I’m stoked on the project. I work with rock bands for context. Just do dope work try not to compare. Remember there are some people with mountains of gear and dope setups they own. much respect to that. Others have rich parents, high interest credit debt, or both. I told myself if I wasn’t rolling in it with a Grammy at 30 I would stop which is a super dumb mindset. I love making records more than anything and getting another gig allows me to keep doing it. Rant over best of luck to everyone 🤙🏽

author: LAPhill
content:
I know I'm an outlier here as a composer, but I very much feel the spirit of the question and would like to offer a few thoughts. My job is about realizing someone else's vision and pushing that to be the best it can be. If you're being hired as a producer, then like me, you have to believe that you're being hired for your taste and perspective. So the question is, why doesn't it feel good to you? Is there something undiscovered that could make it better?

I've written a lot of music that's outside of my aesthetic or personal tastes. But if I'm on the project, I'm going to be 100% invested in helping make that thing what it needs to be. There's a way into music that's outside of your vibe - sometimes it's getting excited about new techniques, sometimes it's exploring a genre you're unfamiliar with, and sometimes it's just because the people you're making music with are a good hang. Sometimes, the role of a composer (or producer) is to take their vision and find the version of it that **does **get you excited. We've probably all had that experience of "I really never listen to X, but this one song/artist is just undeniable." So strive for that.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Quite a bit.

My learning is less music-focused these days, but I budget a lot of time for self-development and continued study.

Sometimes it's  20 min a day in a technical book that I'm reading. I move slowly and make sure I understand before I move on. It may take two months to complete, but I'm steady with it and I do a little bit most days. It's common for me to transcribe notes from high-density talks that I want to learn from and revisit them often over the span of a week. I'm constantly printing out my notes and reading material so that they're easy to revisit throughout the week.

I'm currently taking a project management course through MIT, which has been great. It's uncommon for me to do formal schooling these days, but this is work related and a direct application to my future capabilities that we thought would be beneficial for the company.

When I buy a new plugin (rare) I set aside time to go through it and turn every knob and try each feature to see what it's capable of. Learning a tool on the spot is a good way to kill the creative flow, so I do the exploration up-front when possible.

Often I'll have ideas for novel ways to use a tool (layering distortion, for example) and I'll set aside two hours to explore it and see what I find.

That said, I think my day-to-day may be quite different from a lot of folks here. My eggs aren't all in the business and pressures of record production, and so I rarely find myself buried in such commitments. I tend to keep "normal" business hours these days and keep a hard separation between my commitments and my leisure.

In fact I'd say that I'm actively structuring my life so that I can retain my leisure and don't find myself overwhelmed with commitments. That's a whole other story, though.

author: Slow Hand
content:
As a soft rule, when I experience something that I don't understand I lean into it, sometimes after a period of being repulsed by it. I'll often find myself continually thinking about a thing that I don't understand, which is usually my cue to lean in and give it a closer look.

Until then I'm constantly theorizing about what it might be and continually updating my mental model as I learn more. Keeping my judgement open the best I can.

It's my opportunity to open up to the world and learn more. It's an ongoing practice and is it's own reward.

It has it's downsides too. Sometimes I take a long time to render judgement and may need to make decisions quicker. I also try not to make many assumptions, which means it sometimes takes me longer to confirm things that other people would take as granted/obvious and just move on.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Most normal people need the idea of time spent as part of the conversation so they can wrap their heads around cost. 

A pastor I used to work with was negotiating his salary with the church board, and part of that salary was based on hours. They asked home “how many hours does it take to prepare a sermon?” He said, “well, x hours and 20 years experience.” 

So recognizing that time is illusory, I think we need to be fluid for that part of the conversation.

author: spectrummasters
content:
As a concept , I think “truth “ is a tricky thing to pin down . It can’t really exist without its relationship to time . Truth changes with time . Imho. 

That said , I fully believe music contains archetypes , sacred geometries and of course waves themselves ,…..that are essentially the cosmos breathing and manifesting . That maths , physics and music all relate to each other , that natures forms , in patterns like the golden ratio to be found in a fern , or an excellent arrangement of a song , that sound and light energy all share phenomena ….these things , the patterns , the scales , the ratios and then the ancestral mind and genetic memory , the ancient truths , instincts , symbolic folklore and intuitions ….as Blake called it …..our imaginations being the direct experience of nature itself ….

When someone taps into that and writes something that speaks from and aligns those realms …..

Whatever the message is , that’s what hits ….its an undeniable connection that we share as humans and brought into communion by the music . 
For good and bad 

That shout example s a good one Ruairi

And also everybody wants to rule the world . 

The arpeggio signals something universal as much as the lyrics 

It’s a timeless voice that music unlocks inside us all . 

That’s my take on “truth “ in a song . And like Cian said , it gives me a profound feeling. It’s so exciting and thank goodness for music . It’s such a magic gift

author: Slow Hand
content:
Well, it's hard to say what's best without a more holistic understanding of who you are and your circumstances, so I’m reluctant to offer any hard suggestions. Making a career in the music industry is what engineers would call a "wicked" problem. It's not something that has a repeatable solution, and what works for someone rarely works the same way for the next person.

That said, I see that you’re from Boston. I lived there for seven years, and the talent pool in that city is tremendous. I think if you found yourself back home in Boston it would be a worthwhile investment to integrate yourself into the scene of young musicians that are centered around the schools in the Back Bay like Berklee, NEC, and Boston Conservatory. There are some immensely talented, diverse, and creative people from all around the world based at those institutions and they all exist within 8 blocks of each other. It’s rare to have such a concentration of driven musicians all mingling amongst each other. This is a massive resource that you can tap into. They're *all* trying to make something great and explore what's possible.

It's a unique opportunity to discover collaborators, build relationships, earn experience in your craft, and build strong connections for the future as you grow alongside these people. On top of that, Boston has numerous recording studios where you can intern and assist. There’s a lot of experience to be gained working in a studio that simply won’t be taught to you in a recording program. Supplement that practical experience with hard work, and some book learning and you can do very well for yourself.

There’s more that I’m not touching-on, but I think if you ended up back in Boston it not be as much as a trade-off as you may think.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@rae this is a great discussion! Totally agree about open communication. It's something Jon and I talk about a lot. Learning how to have difficult discussions (even just learning 10 different ways to communicate "that still isn't good, let's do another take") is such a huge part of what we do. But honest, open communication is almost always the best solution. 

The only other thing I'll add regarding @Zack Hames's initial question is that I find it super valuable to continue to do all kinds of different roles. If I've mostly been programming and finishing productions, I'll take some time to write a song and sing it myself, so I stay "in shape" with writing and recording vocals. If I don't do something myself, how can I empathize with someone? My communication style is always one of "I know how you're feeling and you can trust me because I've done it a ton."

author: peterlabberton
content:
In my experience, if I’m mixing and not also producing, there’s almost always (maybe just always always?) someone who can act as a tie breaker. The producer, lead singer/songwriter, guitar dude who is clearly leading the charge creatively, a manager, etc. etc. who you can turn to in order to give definitive direction... maybe during covid this is more difficult as I feel that often can become clear organically in the room.

If it’s truly a situation where there are contradictory/unproductive notes coming in, maybe either a) tell them they need to decide amongst themselves and then give you a clear list of notes, or b) take the lead yourself and really push for what you feel serves the song best/explain why the sax can’t be 10x louder than the lead vocal? Which option is best I’d say depends on your relationship with them, how much of a lead you want to take creatively, how confident you are in making the right choices for this song, etc. etc.

At least that’s what I’d do. 🤷🏻‍♂️ @cian riordan might have better advise for these situations!

author: cian riordan
content: Again, thats where I'll use my ears. These days I'm using some combination of Ozone 9, Pro-L2, and K-Clip on the master. Somethings get goosed more than others during the mix -- often times taken out of the chain. Then when it's print time, I'll take 5 mins and peel back volume at various stages to see if anyone direction sounds better... typically just paying attention to low end transient detail. Sometimes it's just as simple as just pulling back the master fader, as that is pre-insert chain in Pro Tools.

author: oaklandmatt

yup. brighter=better to a lot of A&Rs, so it makes sense that this is the default for a lot of people. i haven't found a mastering engineer i love since tom coyne (rip) for this exact reason. my mixes often come back brighter and it annoys me. 

i had my first mix mastered by Dale Becker recently and he made a great midrange adjustment and didn't touch the high end. obviously Jon talks about him a lot, so that co-sign plus my one experience will make me go to him more in the future. 

also, a good mastering engineer should take the note "i don't want it brighter." they're pros that want to do great work and be hired again. you're the client, so don't be shy about telling them.

I master projects all the time, both that I mix and don't mix.

author: cian riordan
content: The same way you can have a mixing perspective after recording. Or the same way you can have a recording perspective after writing. It's just a different process and you adjust your mindset accordingly. I agree that slapping a limiter on your mix isn't mastering. But plenty of mix (and recording engineers) have the skills and the equipment to create an adequate master for delivery. You may disagree with the quality of the work, sure. But to say it's not the 'correct' process I think is a blanket statement and just hasn't born true in my experience.

author: cian riordan
content: Nice ribbon (RCA 44 is my typical choice, 4038 can be a little too midrangey) about 3-4 ft off the bridge is usually the bulk of my sound. Pepper in room mics if you’ve got a nice space. Usually a good amount of EQ to pull out the “honk”. The cleanest, quietest preamp is usually the one for strings, especially if the playing is dynamic . I’d often used my Grace pre when a UTA pre wasn’t available. I would avoid inexpensive condenser mics like the plague… ive had better luck with an SM57.

If you want to get very deep and nerdy Dave Moulton’s *Total Recording* is incredibly dense and will keep you busy unpacking it for years.

Books 1 and 3 are very technical, but I find the Bruce Swedien book strikes the right balance between technique and inspiring my musicality.

author: Zack Hames
content:
You’re going to get a lot of different responses, because there’s a lot of different answers! I think you already know what needs to happen; I’d think more about how.

Try one song a day for a week. Focus 1000% on the songwriting and almost nothing on the Sonics. Even if you don’t write a full song every day that week, I bet you’ll have spent more time than you would have without that goal. 

I’ve written and recorded some songs in a day. Some have taken literally 10 years. I’d try as many writing exercises that motivate and inspire you. Songwriting is 100% a muscle you can exercise.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Yes. The same way you do anything in life you want to get good at. Spend a shit load of time doing that thing. There really are no hacks or work arounds if you want to actually get good. An easy free way to do it is just learn as many songs as you can. If you want to really be proficient in the musical language I would recommend learning stuff by ear. It takes a lot longer than looking up tutorials or sheet music. But I promise you will develop your ears infinitely more. Specially in the beginning. Music is a language. Every human being learns to speak and converse before they learn how to spell and know the rules of grammar. Learning theory will only let you put names to sounds so that you can convey musical ideas to their people. Contrary to what a lot of people think, there are no rules, but there are a lot of conventions and traditions, but they keep changing and have lots of exceptions. Learning a shit ton of songs on whatever instrument you choose, will teach you what those conventions are and how to use them. 

In the beginning it’s good to just learn every song you like as well as you can, because it will help keep you motivated as you like the music. Then after a while you will probably want to branch out and try stuff you’ve never listened to or enjoyed before just to challenge yourself. 

The most musical people I know, are the people who wouldn’t know what to do with a Caugmented#9 but can listen to a song once and play it nearly perfectly, because their ears and musical language is so developed from playing a fuck lot of music and not spending time reading about it or watching endless tutorials.

author: Will Melones
content:
I used to work for another store in the guitar center corporation, and GC’s turnover was worse than McDonalds’. This was when GC was doing relatively well—only the second bankruptcy or so. Sales reps would start and make great commissions for the first 3 months and then lose their enthusiasm, and commission was ALL they were earning. Sick discount, no paycheck. So I understand the struggle, and it even caused me to appreciate Sweetwater’s dedication to customer relationships in the beginning. Hell, the store I worked for kept a binder of “lead sheets”. Oh, a customer mentioned interest in lessons, or renting a violin? Better take down their info and call them every week when business gets slow.

But like I also don’t want a plumber texting me back to follow up. It just feels lazy and unprofessional, and unlike email or a phone call it strips you of your ability to control the pace of the interaction.

author: austenballard
content:
a number of years ago I consulted on a music tech curriculum for grades 10-12, these were some of the key points:

- Teach the fundamentals, always in a practical way. E.g. "Today we're going to record ourselves speaking" - briefly introduce how a microphone works, what a preamp is, and then get them recording each other. Same with EQ, Compressor, Reverb, Delay, etc.

- Use as many examples from current pop music as possible. Does someone in the class sing or rap? Have the students go through assembling a vocal chain with a compressor, EQ, etc. and record part of a song.

- Don't get too far in the weeds where it's not necessary. High schoolers DO need to know why we have different sample rates and bit depths. They DON'T need to know about aliasing, oversampling, clocking, or dither algorithms.

- Bring history in for context, but don't dwell on it. It's cool to know that we used to need a speaker in an echoey room or a giant metal plate to make a reverb, but focus on how and why they're using effects rather than where they came from

author: Zack Hames
content:
This is the double edged sword of audio interfaces being so cheap and available and marketed. *someone* will do the work for cheaper. (race to the bottom) 

I love artistic autonomy - every musician should be able to record themselves and understand that process and any budding engineers should be able to get into it without spending a fortune.

These are great and big questions. When Jon C. talks about his mix rates it makes a lot more sense (including a studio fee, etc) and is comparable to other industries in the world. But until a label is paying you and independent artists are your clients, there’s just not a chance you can charge like that and get work. But I think that’s why there’s so much talk about raising your rates and valuing yourself and also providing value and having higher stakes projects. 

Anyway, rambling. I know other smarter people will chime in.

author: spectrummasters
content: Wellllll, as the person who asked the opening question , re: marketing and perceived value, it did seem to open up a broad discussion with a lot of varied input . Wherever it got into any perceived sense of entitlement , was off track as the core of the question was about leveraging and better pay/benefits for the successful elite (nothing to do with people striving to get there ) . It wasn’t a question about working hard.....or having talent......or how to share a pie and how much pie there is ......that’s all a given in the original discussion I referenced that was between two Grammy winning engineers.  It was a discussion about marketing and the idea of engineers  leveraging for more as a community looking forwards . One  platform was mentioned here earlier that I have experience with.......and they are definitely driving value down with their marketing.  Through the history of time workers have had to fight for more (pay/benefits/better working conditions / contracts ) and imho that’s a legitimate and beneficial force in society. Noam Chomsky describes a point at which society collapses is when the imbalance of the societal structure is such that the vast majority of the workforce can no longer afford to live . In the uk we are currently experiencing strikes across many services/industries. It’s not really my way to say if they are write or wrong ......but I think the concept of unionising and leveraging for “fairer/better :::::whatever you like “ is legitimate not entitled or moany  . The suffragettes did it ......I digress. I think IME it’s a fair observation that people employed on the business side of the music business in the big music companies in the  uk work with the expectation that this will result in take home regular pay, without fear of non-payment , working with full benefits re’ holiday pay , maternity pay , etc etc.......

author: BatMeckley
content: Having worked in both, music business is different than business business. Good to try and take some lessons from one to the other, but dangerous to make too many correlations that don’t actually apply.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Without question. And there’s much that can be gained from approaching the music business like a regular biz. Little things like, “deliver on time”, “respect bugdgets” “HAVE budgets” etc. that can really help you make and keep your money.

It’s just also a very specific market with very unique parameters and people, so how a software company is run won’t be a one to one parallel on how you should run a production career. A bit like a pet store owner outlining how to take care of a new puppy to a person that just bought a Canary. Definitely give it food and water, but there are some specifics that require a very different tact.

author: Josh
content:
Might be a little soul crushing but he has a bigger advantage than all of us rn because of his age so it wouldn’t hurt to be a little blunt. Might get his butt in gear. But I’d basically frame it as it can’t be a career and won’t be a career until you build d the numbers. Being an artist is being a business owner. Except it’s more like owning a business that invests its money in slot machines. 

His first step is gonna be writing 100 songs. Because they’re all gonna be not that great. I think it’s important to instill the idea of not being precious with your art early on because I think we all spent way too long on that one song when we were 18 and it was awful anyway. 

Then he needs to connect with other people with the same goals as him. Find or build a community. Play shows as often as possible and see how people react to your music. Save up the little bit of money for studio time. 

After doing that for like a year or two start recording and keep networking.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Honestly on pure sonics AT graph is still the best sounding to me, and if Im on a song with a great singer and a great take and just need to tweak a word or two I’ll just audio suite it and call it a day. 

To answer an above question I just bounce out a 2 track instrumental, and import that into Melo as ref track up top, set the tempo, import however many stacks of vocals and get to work.  When doing it this way MD  stand-alone has the edge over the plug-in because it’s all right there in front of me. It’s easy to visually reference a quad tracked lead vocal, and then align and de ess or consonant 8 harmonies. That’s where the stand-alone really shines, is massively dense stacks vocals like that, and not having to keep opening up a plug-in to change a different part or vibrato or formant of a particular track  of the stack or what not. Especially once you get the groove locked in on the lead, it’s just so easy to make all other 30 tracks lock in with it. 

For a solo vocal soul song? I’m probably just audio suiting AT in graph mode in PT. It ultimately sounds the best.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
I’ve been using a nice workflow for AirPod checks recently.

1. Have an output from your monitor/output bus (I have it on a send in my template) to PT Bridge

2. Open QuickTime and open a new audio recording (Cmd + shift + N). 

3. Select PT Bridge as the QuickTime audio input. Turn up the volume slider to monitor

4. Select AirPods as system output 


Hey presto. Works great, no need to stream to phone etc. Just have to remember to turn down that QuickTime volume slider when you flip back to speakers. Also I occasionally accidentally start QT audio recording with spacebar when meaning to hit play in Tools. No biggie 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Deleted User
content:
@joshbonanno said:

i think the premise of this stems from the constant fight that i feel like we all face... 

wanting something to be the "best" it can be (at least in our personal minds and perspectives) vs the sometimes reality that we are hired to do a "job" and not everything is going to meet our expectations of what we personally think is great. 

because at the end of the day, we aren't the artist. In some cases, even the intended audience. with that said, if someone is looking to hire me and my immediate gut says "this isn't great, everyone before me did a bad job and i am going to have to save the day" i immediately question if i am even the right person for the job as thats obviously not an attitude i really want to bring in to a collaborative process with others constantly thinking badly about everyone before me. 

/ might mean i just dont understand the record itself. in the cases that i do take the job though, i typically just try and shift my mindset to think and assume that it made it to me this far and everyone signed off on it. 

so who am i to say its "bad" or needs fixing outside of what i was hired to do? maybe the bad vocal comps and slightly off time drums made it through the production stage because they liked the raw human nature of it? maybe their idea of life/color/mojo is different than mine and they're more sensitive to certain sounds etc....idk. 

this is maybe mainly more of a response pertaining to what i do as primarily mixing day in and day out and maybe doesn't translate as much to the production world. but i still think theres some connected ideas in that line of thinking. if the artist is happy with a sloppily played acoustic take that feels uninspired...you re-tracking and double tracking guitars that are on the grid and feel exciting to you doesn't always make it "better" in the artists mind or vision.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
Not shit talking BBC, or my own products... but on a BIZ TIP for younger me out there: Don't assume there is no reason to push for players because you have great sequencing skills and $50k worth of sample libraries.  When the production company wants world-class sound, and it's your job to create the budget...   knowing that sample libraries can only take you so far is key to explaining to the client WHY they should allocate budget for humans. "I can create this with just the computer, and it will sound great....  but it won't sound like your example.  There's a real VALUE to humans playing the music and that extra 10% of the quality you're looking for requires a studio session with real players" 

Instant path to budget upgrade.  Suddenly the expense makes sense to them.  Now you get the pleasure of hiring all your friends and deliverying something that sounds top notch...  and you can take the client on a mind-blowing field-trip.  It took me years to learn this trick...   clients don't want to pay mountains of money extra for you to sit in front of your computer and massage CC lanes....  and if they have a mindblowing time in the studio and the track sounds ALIVE?  You win six different ways.

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: The only thing I have to contribute is I work with folks in the 23 - 35 age range regularly (Im 44) and younger people who are HUNGRY to move up and ahead in their career get easily frustrated that things don't just happen for them when they're feeling like they're sacrificing a lot for very little recognition. There is also a lot of pushing and pulling the artists to fit their expectations instead of serving the art and letting nature take its course. Specifically theres a lot of "I can't wait to help you realize the full expression of your music and art when we work together!!!!!!!!" kind of vibe which is great internally but puts off older artists a little bit. I've seen it a lot over the last couple years with young producers and engineers and I wonder if its because of the pandemic, honestly. The whole "check list to success" thing is another good point. Some things are not easily repeatable or scalable with the expectation of the same result every time.

author: tim adamson 🇦🇺
content:
I'm a bit confused by the "bottom up breadth wise" language but I take him to mean that it's good to take on a concrete project that will implicitly define the knowledge/skill set that's necessary for it to be achieved. IE "this is what's needed for x and here's the pathway to actually obtain it"

I've seen a lot of people try and learn x by randomly shooting out a dozen questions with zero methodology. Usually the questions don't follow from, or relate to each other which ends up with the "knowledge" being disembodied surface level data at best and it doesn't seem like it's even relevant to them  that what they're learning is applicable to the real world

This has gotta be one of the worse ways to learn imo, typically you'll see the same person asking the same question a week later with no memory of what they'd learnt or why it's even relevant, there's zero chance of this kind of approach getting you "knowledge" that you can actually implement which should be the goal

I like Andrejs post a lot, esp when it seems like the bulk of the world is loosing their value in doing the more difficult and meaningful things in life, along with their attention spans

author: Slow Hand

I'll take a swing. It's 1/4 of the price of an OP-1, it's half the size of a Push, it's tightly integrated with Live, it's a standalone tool (if you desire), it's battery powered, and it's portable.

The biggest features for me are that it can fit on a desk without taking up massive real-estate and gives me the ability to play in drums, keys, *and* have 8 mappable encoders that are tightly synced with *Live*. author: Ross Fortune

Until they’re proven under fire, values are only ever aspirational. And what comes out in the wash is sometimes surprising.

I feel like there are so few *knowns*, at least in my life, that we’re only ever moving through and towards the unknown.

I’ve always found it difficult to identify and articulate my own values, but there are patterns that have emerged naturally that I can observe through the choices I’ve made and their rationale. So I don’t think about any of this stuff too much - just trust the gut and take each decision as it comes.

author: BatMeckley
content:
I was going to discuss this a bit on my birthday, but a big part of the reason I give Cian so much guff on here publicly is because I saw a lot of pearl clutching for a second. “This producer works me too hard”, “this person insulted my hair, can I work with them” etc. 

A music career is rarely experienced entirely alone. You WILL have to deal with other people, and often time they’re… “artists”. They’ll be mercurial. They’ll be quirky. They’ll take work. And that’s ok. A huge part of making a living in this business is to learn how to stick to your guns without being just completely insufferable. 

I hate Cian’s speakers. I hate him even more. But he makes a mean martini, so I go over to his house for work, and even recommend him for things. That’s how the real world works. 

Find something in someone you like, and cultivate something interesting about yourself. Then go diamond.

author: Zack Hames
content: As an engineer/mixer, How do you keep the perspective of the musicians you work with? After so many of years of being on the recording side of the glass and recording myself every day, I find myself forgetting what it would be like to trust someone else to record or mix something I’m creating. A lot of my thought process is on “finishing” and “by any means necessary”. I often wonder if I’d be as open minded as a musician in a band in a studio as I try to encourage my clients to be. For example, using someone else’s gear, the engineer making bold mix decisions/production choices, adding parts, etc. obviously some of these boundaries should be set before you dive in deep into a project. What are things that the musicians are thinking/experiencing emotionally I might be overlooking?

author: rae
content: I primarily am on the musician side of things and only in the last year have I moved into the production world but my thought process when someone is recording me stems a lot from insecurity (are they going to be able to do anything with what I’m playing/singing? Do they understand my vision with this track? Etc.) everyone is different and idk how you approach the deeper conversations but I’ve had bad experiences with being recorded so having those conversations could be good - not sure if this was what you were after but maybe food for thought 🤷🏻‍♀️

author: Zack Hames
content: I think the fact that you’re reflecting on it is meaningful. The reality is, for a lot of artists, we may be their first recording experience, their first record, etc and they’ll grow a LOT during and move on and grow. I think this was mentioned In the Conversations podcast. So for me sometimes it’s letting certain things go that aren’t going to change in someones performance and trying to make it work. I did a pretty emo influenced record recently, and the vocalist isn’t the best. I tried to give him tons of vocal tips and train him the best I could, and it ultimately made it so much harder to record him because it sounded so unnatural and unemotional. We ended up using a lot of earlier scratch takes for certain songs (and they feel super good/relatable/captivating even though it’s maybe nasally) and then using particularly emotional driven takes at the very end. I think there’s a balance of being honest/giving feedback and being delicate/not destructive in your response. Also, @oaklandmatt , your point about learning 10 different ways to say something needs to be better, is spot on.

author: dominic_feverspeak
content: I feel all of this. I do a lot of tracking and it’s my favorite part of the process because interacting with the musicians during the moment of capture is really exciting to me. My two cents: if there isn’t a designated producer in the room and you’re fulfilling both the engineer/producer roles then trying to get from load in to recording as quickly as possible seems to work well - that way they can be witness and collaborator to any sonic changes. Like someone was talking about a producer who just dampened the toms right away - maybe that was necessary but if the artist hasn’t heard both options in the same room on the same song then they’re left with nothing but faith that this is the right decision. But if you just start recording quickly and then chime in with “hey, I feel like maybe the toms are ringing out for too long, can we try dampening them on this next take?” They’re probably more likely to try it out.

author: Slow Hand
content: @Dodgy One reason for the specific listening levels that are being mentioned are because of what are called Fletcher-Munson Curves. The gist of it is that we (humans) hear a balance of frequencies differently depending on how loud or how soft the sound is. This affects our ability to accurately judge what the actual balance of a record's frequencies are and make good decisions about a mix. These researchers (Fletcher and Munson) did a lot of research and came up with a chart that shows how our perception of sound changes depending on how loud a sound is. The general takeaway from looking at these results is that we perceive sound as closest to neutral/flat when listening around 80dB and thus it is the least compromised level to listen at.

author: peterlabberton
content: Personally, I don't really bother taking these kinds of notes while tracking. If I'm producing something myself, I prefer to just keep moving and try something, then move on as quickly as possible. If it needs to be redone for some reason, I'll just cook up a sound again and not get too hung up on whether it's identical or not—chances are if we're revisiting it, things could be improved anyway. If I'm engineering for someone else, I'll defer to them, but these are usually situations where things are even *more* time-sensitive (i.e. we're renting an expensive studio), and the situation is very unlikely to be recreated anyway. I was very lucky to have subbed in for @cian riordan with St. Vincent for a couple months in the early stages of this new record—nothing was documented (unless I grabbed a quick photo to cover my own ass), it was all just trying stuff, and if it worked it worked, if not, move on and forget it! Mixing is another story—in the (increasingly) rare instance when I'm mixing on a console, I'll figure out some way of recalling for that particular project. This is usually more or less @Rollmottle's method, except I go even more jank-ass and just scribble song names on a post-it and hold it in front of a piece of gear like a mugshot. Anything on the console is either stored in the console automation, or, like the most recent project I mixed on a console, I'll just calibrate all the faders and run stuff through it, but really *mix* in Pro Tools still. 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Eric Martin
content:
I’ve been using my best TUBE LDC, placed 3-4’ above the instrument off the f hole at a 45° angle, you can move the mic left to right and hear how it changes the sound drastically. The room is gonna be important because the violins sound doesn’t fully develop until at least 4-6’ from the instrument, so if you want a balanced tone without room, you have to kinda chase that sweet spot.

I’ve used Ribbons and SDCs, Ribbons are nice and smooth sounding which takes the bow sound if you have to get closer to the instrument, where an SDC gets lots of the bow hair scratching over the strings which can be a perfect for a “fiddle” track in bluegrass if that’s the style of violin that’s being played.

You can use a ribbon, but you need a lot of clean gain otherwise it’ll get noisy, violin isn’t particularly loud, that’s why in an orchestra there’s so many of them.

author: oaklandmatt
content:
@David Fuller it seems like the Jon Castelli "finisher" role is going to encompass mastering at some point soon. everyone is already "mixing" as they produce and write (in the traditional sense of balancing and eq'ing and compressing). then someone like jon takes *the existing mix* and finishes it. the argument of having an experienced ear outside perspective is totally correct. that's what a mixer now is becoming. then from there a mastering engineer does... another even more subtle layer of sonic refinement but only to the 2 track bounce? and then decides how loud it will be? i get that this has some value, but based on the evolution of the technology and the roles of "mixers" these days, it seems like hiring a mastering engineer is going to become a luxury equivalent to hiring a second co-mixer or something. or getting real strings on a record or something. 

why spend the money if you already have one sonic finisher?

author: oaklandmatt
content:
i'm not actually quite saying that. i'm saying that most projects will only need one "outside ear" at the end of the process. mixer/ finisher/ mastering engineer will be one role rather than two. 

mastering used to be about technical knowledge for delivering different physical media. it was also nice to have one extra set of ears on a project after the tracking/mixing engineer (who was the same person from the 1930s to 1980s). but now we're going back to the tracking engineer and mixing engineer being the same person (possibly the producer and writer as well). there really only needs to be one more step. mixer/ mastering/ finishing gonna be the same role.

also fully agree that quality will continue to decline as more technically untrained people make music. 

btw i'm not arguing good or bad for any of this. just seems likely that's where we're headed

author: Deleted User
content:
Hmm. I’m a young person in early 20s, so also seeking advice/people’s thoughts on this.

Wouldn’t you say it would be better to be decent at all of the things mentioned above for paths like producer? It isn’t required to be good at all of things because hiring other people is always an option, but starting out- I’m working with projects with lower budgets where people can barely afford to hire a producer.

For example, I would work on my instrumental skills, engineering skills, and arrangement skills- but I wouldn’t necessarily seek to pursue these career paths unless I was asked to because I know that primary focus is in production. I would still take gigs in different areas if the pay my bills, but if I get to a point where I can make full living exclusively from production work- I will not take other gigs unless I’m passionate enough to the point I wouldn’t mind doing them for free. To sum up my thoughts or desires on this- I want to build proficiencies in all areas because I believe they are part of the path I want to go through. Although I wouldn’t necessarily pursue a career in those areas I’m developing but I will still take the gigs until I’m paying all my bills and able to build proper savings solely from one thing I would ultimately want to do.

author: jantrit
content: I worked in kitchens for a long time, it allowed me to make some cash and live but also have flexibility to take music and studio jobs when they would come around. After moving to the states I found more restaurant work but kept it to only fri/sat/sun and tried to focus the rest of the week to build contacts and do studio stuff. I got super lucky with my boss who was also in the music thing and very understanding about calling out. It eventually got to the stage where I had to call out like 3 weekends in a row so I made the jump to doing the studio stuff full time. So far it’s been working out and I’ve been lucky to keep a good basis of projects, supplementing quiet periods with studio build stuff. It can be super stressful relying 100 percent on the music thing and it’s ultimately different strokes for diff folks. I’ve seen some people who get really burnt out taking music stuff that they don’t like to pay the bills and conversely I’ve seen people getting burnt out doing other stuff that’s not music getting effected in the same way. Ultimately whatever keeps ya happy and works for you is awesome, burn out is real.

author: Deleted User
content:
From my experience of going to music school and taking a whole bunch of courses that are all over the place in terms of lane of focus- school can offer almost too much. It helps to take some time to digest the information, I had this issue when I was in college and had a chat with some of the graduates and they said it took them years after graduating to decompose information that was learned. If you have doubts on if you should continue it may be useful to take some time off and spend on doing what you wanted to do, continuing to connect with people, or even just take breaks altogether to take a breeze of fresh air, live in outside world. Being in school kind of made me live in a bubble and getting out of that was really precious to me. 

Degree is just a piece of paper but academic settings can widen horizons of what you can access on your own in the future without having to rely on someone to feed the knowledge/information. It was very chaotic when I took a whole bunch of unrelated courses in college but they all offered me wide insights on what I could dig deeper into in the future. Did I transform as much as others that focused on one lane (eg. engineering) - then I would say no but I created my own program to gain things that would take me more than a decade to have access to. I wasn’t able to retain everything but it unlocked the ways so I can go there when I need to. 

It always sucked having no time to work on my own stuff, but I saw it as a training period  of my life rather than practical period of life. 

My case is slightly different than yours because I went to college straight without having much real world experience. But TLDR; I think semester or a year off would give you what you need without aborting any of the options!

author: Zack Hames
content:
Schools not important. Education is.

I went to a trade school for audio, a working recording studio that also had very well made and structured classes, walked away with a portfolio and having had been lead and assistant engineer on dozens of sessions. I don’t blame anyone for hating their school, hating the idea of school, etc. I just got lucky and I owe my entire career to that experience. 

Audio is not a field where the piece of paper means a god damn thing. It might help you when applying for more corporate adjacent jobs but I work full time, salary, for the production team for marketing at a huge company, im probably the only person in the entire marketing department that doesn’t have an actual college degree.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
When I was doing more prod, I had an ableton template that split my drum rack out onto audio channels, labelled “Drum 01, 02, 03…”. Any that were used would get a “kick, snare” etc label. 

When I got to a point with a beat where it was sounding good/I felt I was done, I’d do an “export all individual tracks”, then just delete any of the unused drum tracks. Obviously kept all the instruments too, this was just the idiosyncratic part for separating drums. 

Hey presto, couple hundred MB folder in a world of terabytes. Takes the same time as bouncing a mix in ableton.
