author: austenballard
content:
> There was a noticeable number of US clients (artists + their entourages, certain producers, and especially writers - usually in pop or hip hop) who treated assistants like “the help” / waiting staff / taxi drivers / some menial worker they felt was beneath them. The first few times it happened, it was kind of shocking, and very off-putting.

I want to add to what Ruairí and Matt B said with another perspective. I've had the privilege of working in some very professional settings, where everyone needs to fade into the background to do their jobs properly, and that's absolutely the case at higher levels. And it makes things work. And everyone's cool about it.

But much of my work has been as producer, assistant producer or project manager/fixer for people working at decidedly lower levels. 

And idk how it is in other countries, but we have a glut of people here in the US who have a certificate from a for-profit recording school that says they know what they're doing, who think they're *the shit* for being in the room with some viral star off YouTube/Instagram/TikTok. But don't know how to use a damn patch bay. 

And when you're on the come up, especially as a writer or producer, you interact with a lot of these people, and you get REALLY sick of them REALLY fast. So that might be the source of some of the condescension you see. It's hard not to get jaded when you have to wade through so much incompetence. I feel like a bitter old man just typing this paragraph tbh but I hope I'm not the only one with this experience.

author: austenballard
content: @LAPhill @Nomograph Mastering tbh it is "kids these days." At least, to a certain degree and in certain environs. It's people my generation and younger who bought into the MDIC and think they have to show up to every session feigning a CLA-type outsized personality and take up space in the room that's supposed to be for the artist. These people need to hear from voices like yours. They're lost.

author: cian riordan
content: When I first got hired by Eric as his assistant, I had already built a multi room studio complex and was making a living producing and engineering records. When I landed in LA for the first session, my mindset was “I can’t wait to show off all the knowledge and experience I had.” I very quickly ran up against the “nobody-gives-an-absolute-fuck-what-I-have-to-say-about-anything” wall. It was very clear that I was there to sit in the back of the room until I was asked to do something… order food, help with a mic setup, shuffle cars in the parking lot, etc. Not to mention working for someone like Eric who is extremely self sufficient… he was terrible at asking me to do things. It was always just quicker for him to do it… even if it meant getting up from the seat and walking all the way across the studio to adjust something. I made the absolute mistake in my second or third week of suggesting something to the drummer in the band after a performance. Eric overheard and pulled me aside. Basically said something along the lines of “yo, you really can’t do that. If you have an idea, run it through me. Absolutely inappropriate, however well intentioned it was. This was really deflating to me. I went from running the show at my own place to spending 14 hrs a day waiting for something to do.

author: ehutton21
content:
Piggy backing on a lot of the great thoughts in here and recalling my own musical education, I would say dividing the curriculum into a “listening” component and a “creating” component would be critical. In hindsight, it was incredibly formative for me that ear training practice and actual theoretical/sheet music knowledge always came alongside the practical element of sitting at keys and performing the pieces I was assigned that week.

I like the idea of breaking down modern pop structure, I like the idea of covering signal flow a lot. I think you can teach and test signal flow in theory while allowing someone to practice their recording technique by mimicking the song structure of their favorite pop song. I’m not proposing that as an actual coursework suggestion (I doubt most would be ready for that week one) but just as a thought for course organization

author: baileybonds

He should be able to get a list of the asset IDs associated with his content from his distributor, in this case TuneCore. I do believe that Tunecore up charges for YT Content ID delivery but if he’s willing to pay them to deliver his audio fingerprints to YT CID, there should be no need to switch his back catalog to another distributor.

author: BatMeckley
content:
Couple of reasons:
1) it’s just easier to carry around, easier to pack, and doesn’t take up  a usb port which are at a premium on the mb pro.
2) I was working with a lot of producers that were just monster fast right off the trackpad on the actual laptop. There was a bit of “lemme see if I can do that” out of sheer boredom.
3) THEORETICALLY, the trackpad offers a higher ceiling than the trackball, especially with better touch tool. The way I worked on the trackball was using the buttons to swap through tools and it allowed me to work really really quick. The track pad has WAY more ways to chord and double/triple 2/3/4/5 finger tap/swipe to program oft used key commands. I’m giving it a year or two to become intuitive.

author: David Fuller
content:
So sound is captured as electrical signals by disturbing a magnetic field (or in the case of condenser mics, changing the voltage potential across a specially tuned capacitor), which generates an AC voltage corresponding to the compressions and rarefactions in the air. This is a whole topic on its own but tl;dr for dynamics you're moving a magnet back and forth inside a coil of wire, with ribbons you're moving the wire back and forth inside a magnetic field, guitar and bass pickup you're disturbing a magnetic field with vibrating ferromagnetic strings... anyway. 

Linear voltage amplifiers (ie class A, and AB for us audio guys) - which we use for mic preamps, line amps, differential amps, power amps, pretty much anything you can think of - work by using an AC voltage to vary DC current flow. In its most basic form, it works like this: That AC signal from the mic or guitar pickup hits either the grid of a vacuum tube or the gate of a FET, and changes the amount of current that flows from one end to the other (usually cathode to plate in a tube, and usually source to drain in FETs). Stick a resistor between the DC power supply rail and the amplifying element and you get a voltage variance because of ohm's law - current goes down, voltage goes up, and vice versa. So, you end up with a bigger version of the input signal, with its polarity inverted. 

Distortion is a *way* more complex topic and not one I'm equipped to explain, as I don't understand it very well myself.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
In most instances, I feel I am fairly remunerated for my work at this stage. On the way to this point though, I did the grind and experienced the impact of that lifestyle on my mental and physical health, and on my personal life and relationships.

I'd rather people coming up now wouldn't have to endure the shitness that can abound, and to that end I sourced thoughts from a bunch of engineers, assistants, producers, mixers, and studios in the UK at the end of last year.

The list below was assembled from those conversations, and details some basic working conditions for music technicians working on a day rate basis (runners, assistants, tape/PT ops, engineers - not mixers, MEs, producers, or songwriters) that would bring us more in line with what have long been established and taken for granted by clients and employers in the comparable industries of theatre and film.

I'm not talking about bringing the industry to its knees here - just about establishing basic working conditions to safeguard the mental and physical health of our friends and colleagues.

I recognise that there are conditions specific to our industry and the nature of our work that would make some of these points less than straightforward to establish, so I'd love to hear everyone's thoughts on the below - whether they're reasonable, actionable, etc.

Pick some holes.

author: shaunobi
content: There’s an idea in software of “proxy based estimation”. So you collect a history of details about past projects. You have to track your time and clock in and out to have the data. So maybe you know past similar “X’s” took 9 hours on average, or 45 minutes. And you know you work X hours on average a day the last month (I usually take a three month average). And you can then bounce a project quickly up against your estimation process (for me it’s a hundred lines in a spreadsheet and some processing based on team composition but could just be 5 lines in a spreadsheet) in near real-time and get a number of hours. You then take that, apply it to your schedule, readjust your plan if needed (ie to accommodate clients with deadlines or other constraints) and let everyone know the plan. Get fast at it and you’ll always have a smooth backlog of work and never have to work more than X hours a day. That’s the theory anyway 😂

author: Barbara
content:
Even though I understand where you come from with this - I guess everyone relates and/or feels more emotionally connected with some projects than others - I think we should own what we do. If you're recording/mixing/producing, do it as best as you can. That can mean passing it on to someone else (and handle this part with care, in my opinion, is also a part of the job). But if you end up going all the way, it still is a worthy project, you should still give it 100% of yourself. Learn something new and useful. And if you do, you should be proud of having your name on something you know you gave your best (even if the rest of it wasn't ideal, your part was the best you could do, at least in a certain moment in time).

So, I'm all for: work in it, own it. But make sure you do your best all the times and always learn something.

author: Deleted User
content:
This can be controversial, but to execute C no matter what artist says or wants to do and present it. That way they can at least have a tangible result to compare it with. Instead of explaining, it’s better to do it and show it.

My humble take: our job is not necessarily doing what we’re told. it is to take their vision, and take it to a place where they could say “wow- I didn’t know this is what I wanted but this is what I want now”. Which I think is the taste and perspective factor. 

It is case by case of course and some artists could come in with A to Z manual of what they want, which can be cool- or not. I personally find those boring, unless I really admire their vision and it just feel like an honor to be a part of it. I think being a yes man can be a quick way to become dispensable. But someone who is willing to serve by giving you some friction that can turn into some heat 🔥 can be someone they find trustworthy and interesting. It’s case by case dependent, some people need perfect aerodynamics to accelerate their vision, and I don’t think that’s necessarily being a yes man- but rather about just being the right fit for the project and being someone who is fully on board to do what they are asking. 

But I think more importantly- it’s okay to miss. If they don’t like it - then scrap it or give it another go. And it’s also fine if you end up not being the one for the project

for what it's worth.  talent I think is often just how things are viewed from the outside. 

by the time I was in my last year of hs I was ort of the national volleyball team back home. 
I'm way shorter than the av player and didn't get picked for any  teams my first year (I was ass tbh) the following year and pretty much every year til my last I was defensive mvp in the state. 

years later when I went back to Haiti post Uni. I joined one of my old clubs and the coach literally told eveyone they shouldn't take me as an example because my practice norms were insane and a few ppl in hs got hurt trying to train as much as I did. 

I did it to compensate for what I didn't have naturally but I was very much pushing my limits and setting new ones. most ppl  just said it was talent. the people who trained next to me would step in and say otherwise back then. 

also been lucky enough to be raised ina very creatively focused family.  my dad is and archi and a painter (using just him cause of proximity but there are others). I've heard countless times how ppl say he's talented, and I get it. his work is insanely good. but my dad is the most disciplined person when it comes to practice /work ethic that I've seen in my life. 

once he decides to practice something he is CONSTANT. man said he wanted to learn tai chi and practiced 2.5 years, every day. only exceptions were emergencies or health reasons. 

it also harkens back to how most ppl tend to compliment results not the work and that has a direct effect on how ppl perceive the relationship between the two. 
huberman ep 133 goes deep into the why of this.

author: Zakhiggins
content:
What mastering really is, is someone with far more experience and reps than you in a highly calibrated room making sure your mix is definitely finished. If you’re just starting out, you probably don’t need it. If you’re looking for that last 5-10%, you probably do. Sometimes they don’t need to do anything other than tell you it’s done (which in my opinion is worth it) and sometimes they have to be more heavy handed. What they actually do (if they’re good) will likely be different every time. It’s about getting the song over the line, and whatever it takes to do that.
You can get plenty of great mastering engineers for 100 dollars or less. Reach out to some peeps on this discord and they’d be happy to help I’m sure

author: BatMeckley
content:
The guy I learned it from (Doug McKean) was just a key command Jedi and had muscle memory on the keyboard, but I mapped out the the three main tools on to the buttons of an expert trackball and it became an absolute necessity for about 15 years of my career. Allowed me to not only be faster than most everyone but also there’s an intuitiveness about it that actually helps you make music, because not having to take your hand off the mouse or “move it to a certain part of the screen to get it to switch tools” just removes another barrier between what you want and how to get there. A bit like learning an instrument to the point where you can just jam and not have to think about how to play it… music just starts to flow. 

The downside was if I ever had to  work without it I felt really handicapped, almost like I was in a different DAW.

author: Matt Huber
content:
I think the biggest shift for me has been to move away from the “buying a house is the best investment you can make” adage that I grew up hearing. 

In some cases, it certainly CAN be a great investment, but it’s definitely not a sure bet, especially considering what else you could do with that money, as some have alluded to. 

Having owned and rented, I am currently a very happy renter - fixed costs, not being tied down to a specific place for 5+ years, etc. 

The amount of hidden costs in home ownership are astounding, and make the rent vs own arithmetic much less clean cut than it initially appears. 

A great example: we bought our home in Nashville and sold it 2 years later when we moved to LA. The home increased in value quite a bit over that time (more than the historical average) - selling for $110k more than we bought it for. Wow! Huge return on investment right?

After the dust has settled and we ran the numbers….it was a break even with renting. 

If we would have taken that down payment and put it into VOO, we would have come out ahead and spent a lot less blood, sweat and tears. 

Ultimately, I personally view rent versus own a primarily a lifestyle choice. Owning a home has benefits (and drawbacks) beyond the pure numbers, as does renting…and all of that has to be a part of the equation.

author: Bryan DiMaio
content:
I feel like that's a bit open ended because different people view the bottleneck in different places, and it depends how many mics you need to record, but I'll take a stab at it:

MBox Studio: $600 (and comes with Pro Tools Studio, helps with flying sessions around even if you aren't a PT main)
Logic Pro: $200
SM7b or AT4040: $300-400
DT770: $170 x2 (record a friend too)
IN8v2 pair: $800
Stands/concrete: $20-100
Cables/mic stands: $50-150
AirPods Pro 2: $200 (obv reasons)

$2790 when adding max values, plus regional tax
more if you add a computer but most people already have one

author: Chase H
content:
nice!!! The big takeaways I get  from Kant are him pointing out certain preconditions for the possibility of experience/knowledge at all.
 If those preconditions aren’t the case then experience itself is impossible.
In short, if one’s worldview denies the possibility of the things needed for experience or knowledge to be possible, then that person can’t even make knowledge claims at all without being self refuting

He was trying to respond to Hume after David Hume tried to nuke Metaphysics. 

Kant like other German idealists is a reallt dense read, a philosophy teacher on YouTube named Daniel Bonevac has some great videos on Kant that distill it down into way more palatable things to chew on if you felt like it.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
**-) **Offline experiences might be a song or an artist being tied to a memory I cherish - that song played at that party when I kissed a beautiful girl, that song played when I was walking out of the bar piss drunk at 6 am with my best friends, that song I heard when I was at a music festival 10 years ago and the world was a better place etc, that song makes me laugh my ass off everytime I hear it (shoutout Frank Zappa lol)

**-) **It could also simply be a piece that moved me when I first heard it and it made me feel something - take for instance** LCD Soundsystem's** *"All My Friends"*, which is to me still the most poignant anthem about getting older, and it never fails to illicit and emotional reaction in me, even though I've never seen them live or have a specific memory attached to them. 

**-) **What makes me become a fan of an artist is - at least these days -  mostly determined by how consistently the artist's work can get an emotional reaction out of me. Take **Bleachers** for example - I had been aware of them for years, but only with this year's album and after discovering "Hey, their songs are actually ALL that good" I became a fan. 

**-)** There are a only a handful of bands/artists I consider myself a hardcore fan of., where I truly explored their entire catalogue over and over again, and it was almost always because they just continued to impress or move me

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
We use clickup, and back when I ran a bigger team we used Monday.com. Asana seems the simplest but least customizable, tried it for a while but ended up going with clickup for the extended functionality.

Clickup: Customizable. Has every function you need and more. Clunky, sometimes buggy. Sometimes has updates that break things. Not good at fast capture, and things tend to take a few more clicks.
Monday: Expensive. Customizable. Good support. Clunky and slow to load.
Asana: Minimal. Does what you need for basic task management for a team. Semi-expensive. Loads fast.

author: NoahNeedleman

I don’t think this is a hot take. Wind & String instruments and the human voice are all kinda impossible to make into a virtual instrument in a completely human sounding way. 

But, a world-class ensemble is often a little out of reach for a lot of self-producing artists and young folks just getting into it, and while something to strive for, shit talking BBC orchestra in this context feels shitty. 

The key is to do interesting things with what you have. Can’t hire the LSO? Make something intentional that gives the same feeling if not the same Sonics.

author: Adam Thein
content:
Found this

“I took the head off a snare drum and started whacking it with a wooden ruler, recording it through a Shure 57 microphone,” he says. “As I did that, I started twisting the hell out of the [API 550] EQ around 1 kHz on it, to the point where it was starting to sound more like a crash. I blended that with a snare I found in the Linn itself, which was a 12-bit machine, so it sounded pretty edgy to start with.” But the coup de grace for the sound was when Z pumped the processed and blended sample through an Auratone speaker set upside down atop another snare drum, which rattled the metal snares and gave the result some ambience and even more high end. The whole thing was limited slightly and then sent to a track on a roll of Ampex 456 running on a Studer A800 at 15 ips. Only a slight amount of reverb was added to the track later on.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
There’s an old saying- good composers borrow ideas, great composers steal them. 

A LOT of John Williams’ most iconic themes are copy & paste from inner voices in things like the Brahm’s Requiem or Tchaikovsky’s Swan Lake etc.  

My advice is take a line from a second verse in a song you love and make that your hook. Extrapolate.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Been watching this all day. Dann seems to have such good character about everything. It's inspiring to see him play with so much care and attention to feel.

I loved hearing him talk about Mutt Lange's approach and how patient Mutt was with every part. Making the players play again and again while waiting for the right confluence of feel to come together before moving on. There's so much care for the moment. That pace is antithetical to the way things are often done today. Understandably so.

Of course, Dann also expresses the feelings of doubt that anyone would go through in his position; wondering what it was about him that wasn't good enough for the take. So I think it's good that Mutt was up-front with the players about how they were going to approach it, which could allow the players to stop thinking about their abilities and sink into the right headspace for such a long endeavor as Mutt explored.

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Sing for real, practice the part a lot. 

No matter how detailed you get in the recording, singing is always a moment to moment performance. So locking in exact timing for onset, releases, breaths, little runs which change your mouth shape, etc…  to do it convincingly is, like I said, nigh impossible. 

But one of the things to make it more or less believable is to have the mic in the same general place in the video as you do the recording. A close mic’s performance and a wide angle video is easier to disbelieve 

And of course in a music video nobody actually expects that kind of perfection so it’s more about the visual energy.

author: Gabriel Tyranny
content:
Timbaland’s talent and contribution to music is something I cherish. Sad when someone of that influence has a take this off base.

I believe the most valuable creative currency of the coming era will be authentic innovation of expression. Creating music that is ahead of the curve of expressing the human experience in a way AI couldn’t have previously copied, since it’s so true to that artist then as a representation of where they are at that time based on all the influences leading up to the moment of creating that art.

There’s always been a flood of copies after something fresh is made, and I believe AI will make it easier for people to follow-up with products like that, but the forefront is too imbued with the energy of the lived energies zeitgeist to be emulated by code - Perhaps one of the few things that code will never be able to do.

I’m open to being wrong, but that’s the thought this gives me.

author: chrissorem
content: This is an important balance you brought up, we have to constantly find ways of keeping the session flowing but also make sure we take time to get things right.  No one wants to watch someone get drum sounds for hours or any sounds for hours yet we expect the results to sound as if we did.  We have to stay out of the way but always be prepared to catch someone falling.  This job is hard, there are many details that go into making  a session go well.  Id suggest thinking about the things you feel need to go further. Are there ways you can be ahead of the curve ?  Are there ways that you can surprise the room and you can say “I  actually just took care of that, we can move on to the next thing”? We have to be steps ahead of everyone else in the room. Some things do in fact take time and you can decide if doing certain things are disruptive to the flow and you might need to bust it while everyone is getting a coffee or telling the room  “ hey gang I need 15 mins to take care of …..”

content:
Fun . Can dig it . I’ve got a 90s midi style production setup alongside my contemporary one . Akai s3000 slaves to the MPC 2000 . Into mixer . 
Only major difference to writing in the daw is timing of the mpc. Be aware if you’re tracking it into your daw it won’t line up on the grid as its timing drifts . So if you like easy grid based edits of overdubs etc it gets a little more complicated than usual . I wasted a bit of time trying to work out the problem then slaving the mpc to daw MTC which then just removes the mpc swing which is counterproductive . So yeah , if at any point it’s gonna be tracked into the daw familiarise and strategise for that asap in the process .

author: spectrummasters
content: I guess it depends what floats one’s boat ⛴️. Part of my process to transition into band mixing is constant listening to indie bands who crossed over to majors in the main scenes in the UK/US since the 70s . Really listening deeply to the recordings and performances . I’m currently discovering kyuss …..and at this point I’m totally addicted to everything about these recordings that sounds completely human . The buzz of it sounding like a bunch of people in a room making a racket ….and some engineer managing to capture and articulate it . Im totally addicted to the humanity of it . The concept of us being archivers of moments , creating a catalogue of human expression is what motivates me . I saw timbos latest AI release and it struck me how exquisitely banal it was . Quite impressive in fact

author: MosesSOG
content:
I rather enjoy this question. Strategies to stay optimistic in 2026. 1-is a compelling vision! A a vision of the future that is exciting and has enough "impetus" or "unction" behind it to get me excited about the work i am taking on and gives me a thorough enough reason to wake up every day. 
2. - consistent prayer and a meditation practise. taking time to do things to ground my self spiritually. i also consider in thiss area study, and fasting at times, and even deliberate training and nourishment - essentially those things which benefit a spiritual life and overall well being
3. living in awe, or allowing yourself to be amazed. intentionally finding things that speak to me or captivate my mind. it is a continuous journey sometimes what used to inspire no longer does so regualy finding things that light my mind up.
4. collaboration/ contribution to a collective whole. there is nothing better than creating something awesome with afriend or brother. that is something that i do take great delight in. creating in a solitude - there is a time and place. yet if i am not connecting with people i love then it feels empty.
5. rejoice. be merry. taking time to celebrate. realizing all of this can be gone. so doing my best to keep that in my mind. there are people in much worse situations, no matter how hard it gets. and there are people who currently wish they had what i had.

author: Zack Hames
content: That’s a super thoughtful response, totally helpful! I think you hit on two huge things, performing in the moment and the bigger picture creatively. For context, a band I’m currently working with worked with someone who, locally, is quite popular which is why they hired them but they did not have a good experience/didn’t like the end result (maybe similar to your experience). they complained that engineer they hired had 0 input good or bad and was not super flexible when it came to sounds (drummer likes open toms as opposed to dead, the engineer basically shrugged and said that it was going to cause problems or something to that effect) So I made it a point to communicate my thoughts on takes as much as possible and make suggestions and guide them when needed. It’s been my first full band project in a while, I was doing mostly solo artist production (where I had a lot of creative input and played a lot of instruments and was dealing with one persons vision instead of 4).

author: Slow Hand
content: Yeah. As with a lot of things in life, if you can explain (or better yet demonstrate) how a change will improve the final product it is much more persuasive than asking for faith. You can say to them "Let's try damping those toms a bit because when they're allowed to ring out they start beating against each other and take up a lot of space that the piano is occupying. Also, when the tom fill leads into the chorus they're still ringing and we want that next downbeat to feel clean and tight immediately afterwards."

author: antoniohannamusic
content:
Hey Rob, so I did a video explaining it (using the older version of the plugin) but in short you create two sessions, an Artist Session and a Producer Session.

The Producer session: Sends full mix + click to artist and has a receive channel

The Artist Session:

Receives full mix, then sends back the performance dry (vocal, guitar, bass, trumpet, you name it)>

In the producer session you then offset your local playback by the roundtrip latency, so you're hearing the artist perform "in time" with your session,

You then just nudge the clips back after each take 😄

author: peterlabberton
content: Guilt not so much, but anxiety—around money—absolutely. I’ve been freelancing full time as an engineer/producer/mixer/drummer for 9 years now, 6 in the Bay Area and now 3 in LA. Easily the first half of my time in the bay was just constant anxiety about how I’ll pay rent/will I work/blah blah. Then things got more solid and I could take my foot off the gas a bit. Was able to relax and feel confident I could make ends meet. Then I blew it all up and moved to LA to start over again! Ha. Not *really* start over again 100% since I had a lot more experience and a tiny bit of a track record, but I’m only now beginning to feel that corner turning again, just a bit. I definitely feel that for me, those feelings correlate to how comfortable I am on, I guess you’d say, the business side and how it’s working out. Creatively I feel like taking time away is always helpful.

author: Slow Hand
content: For some people they will feel strange asking for what feels like a lot of money, but it really does help. I had a shy relationship with money for a long time and it only hindered me. You have to be able to explain to yourself and to others why it has to cost so much. You're a business owner and you have to account for A) overhead (studio, gear, business expenses) B) a liveable wage to earn C) you need money to make enough profit to put some in the bank for long-term goals and D) You are providing a service that doesn't always have a clear-cut point of completion. It will take as long as it needs to and sometimes your clients will come back weeks or months later and ask for something more. You need to budget for all of that.

author: Zack Hames
content: What daw are you using? Also preach on there being 0 videos. All the editing I learned was from audio school actually. Big picture, just don’t be afraid to do whatever it takes to make it right. Cutting, nudging, stealing parts from other parts and placing them in different areas as needed (even just syllable sounds or cymbal decays or dead air) cross fading properly to make the edit “invisible”. And if you’re in pro tools, beat detective is huge if you can learn it’s quirks.

author: Zack Hames
content: Also, always edit/comp what you have before overdubbing more parts. If you do a bunch of overdubs to unedited uncomped takes and expect to “edit it all later” you’re in for a world of hurt.

author: cian riordan
content: In a space that small, as much absorption as you can have will help you. Do you have a bigger room to record in or do you need the isolation? You'll likely get better sonic results if you can find a room with some more volume... that will also allow you to play with position in front of the microphone. As far as the level you should record at, if you've got any half-decent mic pre than you can go into the computer pretty conservatively. Assuming you don't have a super noisy chain, there'll be plenty of headroom in a 24 bit recording to bring it up after the fact. If you're looking for numbers, I'd shoot to get things into your DAW at around -18 dBFS. Many of the plugins modeled after analog gear tend to be happier with that level (or less if you're unsure).

author: Slow Hand
content: How do you think about the balance for something like that? I'm in a writing phase right now for a ten-piece band with horns, percussion, two vocalists, and a full rock ensemble. Lately I've been trying to write songs that are simple and direct and will be just as effective with piano and voice as they would with the band. I'm really trying to nail this before I move onto the orchestration, where I eventually want to take advantage of all the cool orchestral things you can do with an ensemble like that.

author: Slow Hand
content: So I'm also trying to think ahead to tracking and production. I like big orchestrations, but I also want to be really minimal and open. I'm typically not the kind of producer who's gonna stack 12 vocals and 4 guitars in the hunt for a massive sound. Not unless they're all doing different things. When y'all are layering parts how are you approaching it? I'm always asking myself, do we really need this? However I love all the ear-candy that you can get with that kind of approach, so I want to encourage that and leave the door open.

author: Zack Hames
content:
How do you guys approach documenting your sessions as far as what chain was used? (Guitar, pedal, amp, mic, preamp, etc etc)

I’ve been trying really hard to always put the chain in the “comments” section of every pro tools session i do for each applicable track. I realize now I do not have the memory to just remember “oh yeah these are 414s on toms” or “this was definitely my greenback speaker cab” or whatever. I just opened a session and I thought I knew what the setup was, but when I did it, it sounded way off. I spent 2 hours A/B-Ing mics and guitar speakers and amp settings to get back and I’m not even sure it’s exactly right - but I do like it better than the original even so it worked out!

author: peterlabberton
content: @GEORGE NFTEAPARTY 🥃 Depends. If it’s a more pop oriented thing with loads of vocal stacks, I’ll just copy everything. Maybe we’ll end up using a different take of the lead, or have some other variation in there. If I’m working with a band on something more organic, I’m more likely to do full takes or at least have some variation, whether subtle or obvious. If I really get my way and it works for the band, we might not have a click, so we’re def doing different takes!

author: Zack Hames
content:
I’m pretty sure Spotify main normalization is set to -14 LUFS. 

In my experience with Broadcast, streaming, Advertisement audio, the LUFS standards have proven incredibly useful and quite reliable. Every project to do for “web” is mastered to -14LUFS, North American broadcast is -24, and Euro -23. Hulu, Roku, YouTube, etc all have their own little specifications for loudness. 

LUFS takes into account perceived loudness whereas RMS does not. It also does not measure or add to the loudness for passages of audio that fall below a certain level of loudness. So if something is far quieter, it doesn’t get factored into the average loudness.

author: Slow Hand
content: The Fiery Furnaces did a really neat live album a decade ago where they spliced together all of their live performances into a full album. Now many bands do that already, but they combined multiple takes for each *song.*  They'd take the chorus from Night 1 and splice it onto the second verse of night 4 and then do the outro from Night 7. The cool part was that the recordings, rooms, and audience are drastically different, so you end up with lots of cool sonic shifts on the downbeats of each section in the songs.

author: hendrick
content:
I agree with matt that hiring a mastering engineer is a luxury in the present day tbh. Most of the records that I get to mix or produce I'm expected to deliver a finished product ready to release. However when a lot of things are at stake (label release) it's almost 100% sure that a mastering engineer will take care to finish the record, do some QC and especially keep a human touch to the art. Would a co-mixer be able to do that? possibly, depending on their skillset/experience.

with the use of AI and other systems the expense of hiring a mastering engineer is already fading away but only for projects that are less risky. Say, if you have a tape library of 500 symphonic recordings and need to submit it for streaming so a few folks can listen to it, labels will most likely get an automated system for that to make sure that the standard levels are ok and that it translates well. I'm sure there would be a hungry mastering engineer willing to get that done but the industry is past that era

author: Eric Martin
content:
As long as there’s someone out there that has listened/worked on more music than the person who is the Mixer or Producer and has a “technically better” or more accurate playback system than said producer there will be a viable job for the ME when it comes to releasing music IMO, not everyone will pay to do it, but the people who want to put out the “best work” will, the job will change, it already has many times, but the responsibility will stay.

FWIW at Abbey Road in the 50’s/60’s the new engineers started in the cutting room so that they learned exactly what was possible to put on the records as it was cut, then they gradually worked  their way back from cutting to working in the room with an artist.

I think this process is insanely valuable, I just did my first “true” tracking session in over a year and after mainly Mastering and Mixing for the last year/two my tracking mixes sounded dang finished.

author: Zack Hames
content: Do you have any way of recording at home? You mention "while you are not actually recording". The best way to practice is to literally do it as often as possible even if it's by yourself. You won't train the social aspect, you won't really train problem solving of an external source (a guitarist with a particularly shitty amp or playing technique per-say), but you can certainly experiment endlessly on capturing sounds. Shootouts, micing techinques, it's pretty much endless. If you don't have a recording setup at home or are in an apartment where you can't be as loud as you'd want, I try to absorb as much information as I can. Podcasts (Andrew Talks to Awesome People / Unstoppable Recording Machine / Working Class Audio / Conversations Audio), Online articles, (Sound on Sound) GearSpace Forum Q+A, TapeOp interviews, Youtube Series (Making Records with EV, Sounds-Like-a-Drum), etc. These can be incredibly inspiring and keep your mind tuned into the recording process.  I sort of use this as my "fix" when I am not able to work actively on a project. Otherwise, what everyone else has said about mixing are perfect suggestions. Maybe set limitations like only using plugins you haven't used. or remove a plugin you are constantly using to force yourself out of a habit. Practice editing dramatically even if the track doesn't call for it so you can get your editing chops up.

author: Zack Hames
content: Also, a HUGE thing I didn't mention: Listen to records! Listen to the best sounding records, CONSTANTLY. i find this has had a dramatic affect in "tuning" my ears to what sounds REALLY great. If you're going for more the songwriting route this can really start to bite you in the ass because you end up listening to a bunch of steely dan, but there's a always a time to switch back to simply listening music you love because you love it, not because it was an excellent recording.

author: ALXCPH
content:
A concept i find really cool atm is fake bass notes using sub harmonics. 
Its basically the overtone Series but in the opposite direction.  Fx. If you take a bass note, lets say C. And u add in a low G under it, it Will produce a C the octave below that you Will be able to hear and feel. 
Its cool to use on piano or guitar when you want super low notes, but havent found many other use cases for it. 
I know alot of classical bass singers and beatboxers use it to reach those super crazy low notes(some of the sea shanty on tiktok as example). They’ll sing a normall bass C and then do a slight vocal fry which for some reason our body vibrates a fifth below the note you sing and it produces a note an octave below that you can hear and feel in your chest, without having to sing super low. 


I cant help but feel there must be some Way to use that concept in a mix to get some crazy subbass with out blowing out your headroom. Just haven figured it out yet!

author: ehutton21
content: Depends. Short answer is honesty on all fronts. Long answer is that (1) I make sure I’m being honest with myself about why I don’t want the work and then (2) I find it pretty easy to be honest about why I’m not in a place to take that particular song.

author: ehutton21
content: Beyond that, just be adamant and upfront about what you do like and see in an artist and let them know that if they have a song you’re more suited towards, you’d be happy to take on future work.

author: ehutton21
content: But if you’re actually cold on them because you’re not feeling the work, I think you’ll endear a lot of respect if you say “hey I think you’re a cool person but this music just isn’t something that resonates with me, and I’m not going to give you my best work if I’m not feeling the project.” And that’s where you could maybe refer them to someone who would be willing to take them on. Honesty followed by (1) a show of good faith discount if keen for future work or (2) a reference to a better suited producer are methods I’ve had success with.

author: ehutton21
content: I think it’s important to remember the dollar today>dollar tomorrow point is true in the context of a choice between two deals/options that are on the table (but even then, you have to do the math to make sure! Just because you have a deal with $1500 now versus $4000 in a year doesn’t mean that you should take $1500 now, unless you need that kind of capital). To apply that logic to situations beyond the time value of money isn’t the whole picture: that law of economics only compares value, it doesn’t tell us that concentrating labor for short term gains yields the best possible business model. By that logic, there is an argument that everyone’s best business decision is to forego longterm relationship building, knowledge acquisition (which is like R&D for producers), and strictly focus on maximizing immediate sales (which could look like everyone hopping on beatstars, fiverr, and enginears) which would diminish resources like this very discord, and probably a lot of reputations too!

author: ehutton21
content: Ahahah nah I definitely didn’t mean to sound like I was coming for you with that, I just think I hear it a lot and the facts about dollar today>dollar tomorrow also apply to costs etc and I see people use that to justify short changing a long term, viable plan for the future. Which is a mistake. Capitalize on the now when you can always, but do so by building a long term plan for the future

author: Will Melones
content: I don’t care about math, I’m talking about solving audio problems with the wrong tool. If a sound reaches two mics at different times (out of phase) because they’re at different distances, you can flip them every which way and they will not line up. And all the audio students in the world can’t figure that out because they’re only taught with graphs of sine waves and not real recordings

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: Good point Peter. And this is very different in mastering than in mixing. Mixing is much more collaborative, in mastering the artist/mixer/producer have all done everything they can, and explored every option. Now it’s time to finish. it's great to be mobile and move everywhere. i do keep my vintage 87 with me at all times, so i have a solid vocal chain anywhere (apollo x preamp is more than good enough with the 87). the challenge is headphones, and i haven't found a solution that replaces speakers. i've tried some different open back headphones (grados, focal clear mg) but they don't have the "oomph" that i get from speakers. the imaging and clarity is better than my ath m50x headphones i always have, but the lack of big bass and the annoyance of open back (can't really use in public, on planes, etc) make them not really useful to me.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: For those wondering full QC is recording back in two test pressings, comparing to the digital cutting masters. Checking for surface noise, distortion, end of side distortion,  HF rolloff, overall tone. Then …. The real kicker, comparing every meaningful click on one pressing with the other. Slow slow

author: Nomograph Mastering
content: If it’s unclear whether it’s go / no go I will upload audio samples of the offending clicks to a streaming link, with timing notes. This allows stakeholders to make a call, and can also be used by plants to locate and fix issues on the mother.

author: Zack Hames
content:
A big turning point for me was my consultation with Unfuck your studio. Rauri and spider chatted with me for I think a couple of hours and it was instrumental in me pushing myself. 

They essentially told me to be in more high stakes situations. Rauri asked how often am “I the smartest or most experienced person in the room?” In regards to producing, etc. almost always - which is the exact problem because it’s not like I’m out here making hits. They were telling me that by working at this lower level, turning C- bands into B- bands, or D+ projects to C+ projects, wasn’t going to get me where I wanted. I need to get in the rooms with higher stakes.

It took a while but that’s exactly what happened. I’m working with people who are insanely talented musicians and writers, some of which are incredible engineers in their own right, but they do their tracking with me now

author: Ross Fortune
content:
**Keyboard players (and songwriters) of LWMR:** I need to seriously up my keyboard chops this year. 

I’ve been keyboard catting my way through life up to now - mashing out left hand root notes and RH triad shapes to get the rhythm and feel down, then fixing the notes / adding removing midi.  Fine by myself, but infuriating for anyone else in the room. 
 
I’m going to be in some (mostly writing) situations where that’s not going to cut it - I need to be much more fluent.

What are some efficient ways to get there? I’ve tried putting myself through the school of YouTube, but I haven’t found a course prescriptive enough to keep me focused and on track - just loads of disparate technique tutorials, and I don’t know what order to take them in. Also took some lessons, but cost and scheduling were unsustainable.

If it helps, my theory and reading were at one point strong and can probably be dredged back up if needed.

author: Ross Fortune
content:
Thank you Noah, but you’ve been hoodwinked! Sadly I only played one good bar of that repeating right hand rhythmic figure on one finger, edited and looped it, then programmed everything else around it. It took ~15 minutes to make 2 passable minutes of piano - I want to be slimming that down to 3-4 mins (a couple of passes, edit, 82% quantise, profit).

The one “technique” that’s been consistently useful to me on other instruments is recording parts. It’s only then that I can really hear what I’m doing well and what needs work.

So good shout, thank you. I’ll fit that in to my song learning routine.

author: ALXCPH
content:
Oh not utopian in the philosophical all is perfect sense, utopian in the post capitalist way. It’s a general term used in the development of things. 

You get something that becomes popular created by passion, then capitalism takes over with money and doesn’t care about the consumer, but develops a whole lot of technology and is very disruptive and does a lot of growth, and then after that, utopia, when the capitalist hype is over the techs has been developed and the original passion is the main driver once again with all the new knowledge that has been developed during.

author: Barbara
content:
They came back with 10 PAGES of comments, with stuff regarding other takes we might had (I forgot to mention, but it was a deal that once I've sent the files for them to continue production, every take and edit was correct and accepted by all of them, in order to commit and make decisions... specially, because it was an edit nightmare, but mostly because I knew they weren't experient and it would be hard to finish anything if we kept having too many options to chose from - which we hadn't. That was indeed the most polished takes and performance they had, and it still needed A LOT of care), a list of reference tracks that wasn't even close in anything to what we had or could ever have, and me wanting not to jump in again on all of that. And during this, I had other people hearing my mix (colleagues) that were harsh on the way they gave feedback - not criticising, I knew it was shite, but I think it was the right thing at the wrong time for me.

At this point, I was struggling so bad with imposter syndrome, I was seriously considering quitting and getting the blues about the process, not happy with the result but not sure how I could do any better. And yes, I was working on other stuff, but this project was sucking all my energy and mood.
Feeling like a fraud and a failure. There is no sugar coating it.
But most of all, I wanted to make it work for the band. I wanted to give them my best, and wanted really hard that my best could be the best for them. So I kept going, and entered into it. 

Version 2... 7 pages of comments, all on different stuff that I thought we already nailed on the first version, since there was absolutely no comment on those things before... 

Oh, by the way, by this time, I was still waiting on some dry tracks from the producer, to make moves that the band asked for on the first version review.

author: austenballard
content:
Speaking as someone who moved to the US, there are a lot of things that will make you miss Europe sorely. Mainly quality of life things, especially if you're moving to Texas (although ATX is not so bad)

First, as people have mentioned, this country is massive. Everything is disproportionately large and far away. You will drive everywhere, which as a German you might not have an issue with, but it gets annoying when you want to pop over to the corner store to grab something and then you remember that doesn't exist, and then you're driving 30 minutes on the highway to the supermarket just to get two things. Normal errands will take you ridiculous amounts of time if you're not in a dense city, particularly east coast cities (NYC ftw)

Next, there's the increasingly Kafkaesque nature of every commercial interaction in the US. People are generally not paid enough relative to their cost of living and are constantly stressed by student debt, credit card debt, auto debt, mortgage debt (if they're lucky enough), etc. As a result, those in many public-facing service jobs do not do their jobs very well. Sorting out a minor problem can easily involve hours of slogging through telephone menus and talking to service reps who can't really help you. An example is it recently took me over a month and 20+ calls to 4 different places to switch my health insurance, which is supposed to take a week at most through an internet portal (Healthcare.gov)

author: Slow Hand
content:
Had an interesting realization with my ex a few months back that was illuminating. She kept insisting that I don’t take things seriously and that my humor was a defense mechanism, something I strongly rejected.

With some discussion what we were able to uncover is that we actually had very different perspectives on the role of humor. For me humor is a venue for creative expression,  exploration, and improvisation and for her she’s regularly used it as a way to defuse her own interpersonal situations and assumes that’s where everyone else is coming from.

This is an assumption that took us a year to uncover and goes to demonstrate how a lot of behavior can go unexamined because we both assume we mean the same thing when we say it.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Totally. That was exactly what I thought when exploring the AI DAW that Ruairi posted last night. "How is this any different than what we already do?" In both cases you still need to specify exactly what you want. At that point you may as well do it yourself, if you're capable.

If you're unable to specify exactly what you want then you're at the mercy of the AI or of an artisan who can interpret your requests. Whatever shape the future of recorded music takes it seems that there's still likely to be artisans steering the ship. Just in a different capacity. 

You still need someone with know-how and with taste to make the call.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Well, I'm no Mozart/Rossini where the music flows out effortlessly. Bad ideas and false-starts are part of the work for us musical mortals. 

I don't see being discouraged by a bad AI generation to be that much different than being discouraged by a bad first-draft that I hand-wrote myself. Just go back to the drawing board and keep hacking at it. At least the AI render would probably take less time to execute before I can try again.

author: LAPhill
content:
Not exactly my point. AI is going to take awhile to replace various aspects of what we do. So creators can drive where THEY see value, in hopes of steering the tech. If everyone here hates timing drums, and an AI can come along to do it while maintaining groove and feel, perfect transients, etc., that saves time and is worth something.

Whether or not that's more valuable to the tech company than offering 50,000 bedroom producers the tools to make "pro-sounding" beats easier than with Splice.... probably not.

author: andrew_yv
content:
An interesting side note re: the psychoacoustic HRTF binaural sound localization discussion from yesterday’s live with @Nomograph Mastering :

I can’t find my source right now but if/when I do I will link it, anyways… A study was conducted wherein moulds were cast of several people’s pinnae (outer ears), these were placed on dummy heads with microphones inside the ‘ear canals’ and recordings were made through each of sound coming from a variety of locations. Some of the subjects were audio professionals and some were lay people.
When the subjects listened back to these recordings, there was significant variance in their ability to localize the sound sources. If I remember correctly, they were generally better at listening through their own pinnae than others were, and audio professionals were a bit better at sound localization in general, particularly in the traditional stereo field. However, the really interesting finding was that there were some pinnae that were universally better or worse. People actually had improved localization through someone else’s pinnae than their own, implying that although we are adapted to our own pinnae, there are material differences that make some better than others for localization of sound.
This is all from memory of reading something a few months ago, so I apologize if there are details that aren’t 100% accurate, but I assure you that the surprising bit is correct!

HRTF-based binaural mixes are not exactly the same thing as dummy head recordings, but I wonder if, in the creation of the aforementioned “baller individual HRTF’s” there might be a place for some optimization beyond the exact copying of an individual’s unique acoustic properties.

author: Rollmottle
content: they offer different forms of coverage. RAID 1 is likely most useful for our purposes, but requires more drives (because data is mirrored across the drives. if one goes down, the other(s) take over. swap in a replacement, the data from the other(s) gets copied over to the new drive and you're back to nominal).

author: shaunobi
content: I resonate with what Jos says above. I've experienced two things over time, both of which I called "burnout". The first is just emotional / creative exhaustion. I pushed it too hard and didn't take care of myself. Things that used to bring me joy hadn't changed, I changed, and I didn't want to look at them at the time anymore. Working out, taking time off, spending time with people you like / love that recharge you, hiking, this sort of thing can fix it.

author: shaunobi
content: The second thing though is when the job itself doesn't have the "thing" anymore. Sometimes this is because it morphed - gig work (which I do just at a very large scale) can really suck the joy out of you. Here you are working, but you're also marketing, you're doing sales, you're chasing payment, you're reviewing contracts, you're "presenting" yourself to other people, you're worried about seasonality, you're thinking about healthcare and taxes and retirement, and you're doing it ALL YOURSELF. I don't work for a big company (I run a small one) but my wife does, and the nice thing here is: you just show up and do YOUR job, you're a nurse and you take care of folks, you're an accountant and you reconcile spreadsheets, etc. Instead we do EVERY job with zero economies of scale, and no matter how much you try to "outsource" it, that costs money, it costs oversight and time and initial effort, and in the end it's a lot.

author: Deleted User
content:
I think the bigger question is the lack of money in recording business. 

No tangible way of making real money off of it for most people except those who are landing sync placements, which can really be anyone. The way I see it is sync placement is fulfilling more of the utility aspect of art, while making records for people to listen to is a more artistic endeavor in service of the people that listen to the records. But the reality is that everyone’s streaming and that doesn’t pay. Even with the biggest success- it won’t make money correspondent to the level of success. 

Budget for record production is now more of a PR for their shows or tours. (As far as what I can tell)

So why in a sane mind would anyone spend money on making it other than for their own satisfaction? It’d be insane to see making records as business investment unless you’re really aiming for sync in mind. But then, what most of us fell in love with are the amazing records that we grew up listening to. Maybe a song from a movie occasionally, but probably not quite a track from sports spot nor a jingle. 

At this point, is there really a way to monetize real money from records other than sync? If there can be, what would that be?

author: spectrummasters

I dont disagree with you that what you are both describing is true for where we are at currently and have been for some time. im trying (badly) to not promote my view as opposed to the views shared by the engineers in the discussion im referencing....but fwiw , in 2022 the global recording revenue i think was around 20 billion dollars. Thats a lot of dough. Im not a socialist....im not against the free market.......the discussion was centred around the growing leverage engineers have in the industry and whether that is being marketed effectively to increase the price of the skilled labour engineers provide. When i first started getting indie production deals i was adviesd in the music business, when it comes to discussing deals, everyone's friends...when it comes to paying on those deals......no-one's friends....its only business. I have found this to be true and have no objection to it.

author: LAPhill
content:
Think about what it means to a client when you say you're going to miss a deadline because of someone else's project. Now they feel like they're not important enough to be worth your time, so why work with you? You might get away with that for a little while with low level indie artists, but you better believe a label or artist with a busy schedule, tour dates, social media promo, etc., is not going to deal with that.

I sympathize with the overbooking - it happens to anyone that's climbing the ladder, trying to take on good work and level up, but you've got to find a way to solve it without making it the client's problem. Get help, don't sleep, whatever you need to do.

I'm not missing deadlines for anybody paying the full rate. I think communication is key here -- don't do discounts & don't miss deadlines. Or continue to offer discounts to people with the clarity that deadlines need to be flexible, or not exist at all. also, part of what's pushing things around is personal stuff (house projects) that I didn't take into account when i booked my month.

author: jantrit
content:
Sometimes you can see them coming a mile away and sometimes you can’t. I feel like the more I do this the easier it becomes to spot and the scales are starting to tip heavily into you see it coming side. I find it helpful to think of each time as a case by case sort of thing. Are you young and just coming up trying to cut your teeth or in a quieter than usual month with bills looming? Then probably you’ll end up saying yes to more things that you would usually swerve. Are you busier than ever beating off business with a 10ft pole, then maybe you don’t need to take this gig. I try and deal with it preemptively in this way, can it be avoided before we’ve even begun? In which case I’d probably swerve the project. If you’re already in deep and working I’d try and just power through like you said. You can always say no next time. If it’s just not possible to do that and you actually have to get out for the sake of your sanity, it might be worth speaking to the artist and saying “hey I’m really sorry but I don’t think I’m best placed here to help you achieve your goals” depending on reasons why you could even recommend someone who might be a better fit (if the person is a total dick I absolutely would not do this)

That’s really a last resort though. Powering through, learning from it (even just being able to spot these things before they start) and giving yourself the ability to swerve them in the future. 

Can I ask what the situation is and what’s making you want to dump the project?

Edit:
I’ve only ever had to ‘fire’ one client in my time (it may about to be two) the first time it honestly worked out better for everyone involved.

author: Josh
content: Working on a track like that right now. Artist is in self discovery mode. Wants to throw away their entire fan base in rock music to do pop (which is pretty damn bold considering they have 2m followers on tiktok lol) and they told me they really want do the blinding lights thing. Which IMO is not a great idea as I think new artists making top 40 sounding tracks is kinda hard to pull off. And then you also have the fact that the whole 80s thing is feeling dated already. I think they need to go more indie since their voice suits the genre and their image won’t have to be tweaked too much and there should be a solid crossover of current fans, but I ain’t the artist here. So I just talked to them about it and told them I’m gonna take a few extra days and make sure this feels right for the above reasons and if they hate it that’s fine we’ll try again until it’s right. So I guess I’ll post his response today when he writes back. I think just being honest and being like “yo your idea is fire but BOTH of us can do a lot better” is the mindset needed for these sorts of scenarios.

author: masteredbyjack

Almost certainly true (I’ll take your word for it)…but the day to day reality has to be that there is already a vision and goal that producers are trying to achieve, and walking that balance is probably very hard.

For us in mastering we are as close to service as we get, if I was producing I’d be all in on “get into the room and let’s we what happens, no boundaries or whatever”…but that’s probably a terrible strategy for a business and living…and weirdly maybe you’d almost have to have a deeper sense of taste and understanding what works to do it that way?

Thoughts on how you bridge that gap @NoahNeedleman or anyone else?

author: spectrummasters
content: 😂 interesting reactions gents . Re rhe caps…..one of my goals is to be able to read a schematic for one of these and understand the physics and electrical processes at work . IMHO they are like a maze of genius . I’m caught up in the concept that electrical engineers were tapped into musical needs and concepts so much that they made legacy mysical momentd possible ( Ye olde Phil Collins SSL LMC drums scenario etc ) . Decades later in the digital world of an instant studio in a box, it’s not really obvious that some super bright tech came up with the routing ideas and then created the electrical circuitry for it . And then these techs would sort of partner the recording / mix engineers in a sort of perfect marriage of art and science . Love it !

author: BatMeckley
content:
Annnnndddd I think it sounds better? Different algorithm. And for me it’s easier to line up doubles and harmonies etc. Its a bit like the smart tool, people usually take a step backwards when they first get away from it, but ultimately find they’re faster after they get the work flow dial in. If you’ve ever learned to juggle, you’ve taken this step as you try to go from two items to three. 

At the same time, whatever works best for you and gets you the results, that’s what you should go with. No rules. A great vocal producer friend of mine has basically (secretly) punted on Antares entirely. Horses for courses.

author: popthetrunk
content:
No worries. If you aren’t throttled on performance on those devices you don’t need to juggle your TB distro. If you don’t need the afterburner I’d take it out. But that’s up to you. 

That owc card is 16 lanes as well and could go in slot 3. I’m not sure how hot that AMD card gets, but you’d wanna look at the manual for installation for that particular model and see if there is guidance on placing that card above a graphics card. Sometimes they aren’t explicit, but will say an acceptable temperature range and then you have to judge based on what you know about your environment.

author: popthetrunk
content:
Great! Re: black magic stuff, that’s out of my domain and I can’t really advise on a decklink. But that would move the load off TB(strictly pool b) and place it on the available pcie(pool a+b)

That owc 8m2 takes 16 lanes, the bandwidth of a single pool, or it can fully saturate slot 3 without impacting the pools. Changing model wise to the 4m2 which can fit in an 8 lane slot isn’t a terrible idea if you don’t need the capacity

author: Slow Hand
content:
Man. I've started trading IG voice memos (via DM) lately with a friend and it sounds *sooo* much better than iOS voice messages. *Miles* better. I was startled by how clear and present it is. It actually sounds like recording through a proper microphone.

It seems like they've got a little bit of DSP going on here: Some noise reduction, some compression, and a little bit of EQ. It's like my phone calls have been in the dark ages and now I'm finally in the modern era.

Which begs the question, why don't phone calls, voicemail, and audio text messages sound this good? 

My guess is that it's some sort of bandwidth limitation because the data transfer protocols were designed and portioned out with decades-old infrastructure in mind. Maybe some latency considerations as well?

Anyone have any insight on this?

author: NoahNeedleman
content:
I did one season of a podcast with a friend who I love chatting with. 7 or so episodes and only one of them actually ended up mattering to me. 

Solid premise, thoughtful approach. Just didn’t work. What we needed was another 20 episodes to find a stride, to see what works. 

I really want to encourage you to lower the activation energy required for making a podcast if you really want to. Make it take as little time / energy as possible.

Dont plan trips to Boston before you’ve even started, cause then you’ll never start. Always ask the question “what would this look like if it were easy?”

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
The value in ALL pop culture is, in general, front loaded.  Across his entire career Rod is reported as earning $300 Million from all recordings, tours, and etc. He squeezed the best out of it then. Being "featured" in GTA or any other modern revival is worth something, but it's not going to net anything near original hit earnings. Especially with royalties still dwindling, in general (aka smaller pie than pre-2004 and more content dividing it up). 

Rod played the game well and is loving this.  I don't think they will roupe.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content:
That's the thing...  I think the earnings of 20th century recordings are going to diminish as the generations die.  Currently catalogs from popular music of the 1940s and 50s...  this peer group is almost extinct.  In 20yrs those catalogs will not have a multiple value, but it will be a diminished return (less than 1x) ....  not a growth (greater than 1x multiple).  

If Rod Stewarts catalog generated $300 Million during the height of his popularity (including tours)...   The value of his catalog over the decades would be a fraction of that.  To recoup $100 Million would require $10 Million x 10yrs in ROYALTY alone to break even. He (reportedly) earned $7 Million from his music in 2013.  So the ROI couldn't profit until 2037 (without touring income).  His fanbase will be effectively extinct by 2040 and it's going to be hard to break 1980s trends on future generations.  You'll get some novelty bumps but I don't know how many Kate Bush moments investors can bank on.  Seems more lottery and less solid investment

author: Deleted User
content:
when we think of how language and words get created out of necessity, we can also use that to work our way back and analyze why certain words become popular or lost its use over time. especially with internet, language started driving a good part of pop culture. we don’t want the words to limit our expressions, we want words to enable more articulate expressions and thinking -> both are happening from what I see. 

Why does the new generation feel the need to minimize and maximize everything? Why can’t we spend our effort into exploring everything in between? 

Do everything in between come with labels or do they become lengthy sentences and paragraphs? 

I think the answer to all of this is complexity of life that us humans brought onto ourselves. That is the cycle of “why older generation can’t understand newer generations”

older generations make the world “better” - (technologies and advancement of civilization & cultural understanding ) for the new generation. But what this “better” comes with many times though, is complicated soup of mess. This causes overload in young people’s minds trying to make sense of this world. Many or most don’t have the patience to keep on trying to explore the nuances in between. Or can’t afford to take the time / invest the energy to do so. I believe the lack of dimensions in the new generation’s language is a product of this. 

@NoahNeedleman said older, less nuanced in opinion & younger, less nuanced in language. I believe both are true for both younger and older people *if they ended up giving up trying to dig deeper to explore and ponder on “everything in between”*. I don’t think age has anything to do with it. It’s just that the disparities between those who had the patience for nuance vs those who gave up trying become more apparent as people get older.

author: Calvin Lauber
content: If you print your mix to a final stereo track, I will change the input of that track from whatever master bus output , to “MON L/R “ - which is the direct feed output of the Apollo. Then I mute that track and hit play on Apple Music (normalization off!) to print. I just record reference tracks straight in as part of the playlists of final mixes, that way when I’m in input mode I’m listening to my mix, and when I take it out I hear the reference. Instant A/B

Good take. My feeling is this too, that the connection to the artist is important (but perhaps not as important to the average consumer as many of us wish/think/experience ourselves). 

I find it hard to imagine fully automated music generation will be the mainstream - if there’s any amount of human curation or modification that will make it noticeably better, that should dominate. 

At the end of the day I think the life lived around a piece of art, the emotions it evokes and the conversation around a piece of art is the main benefit for humanity. Perhaps if we zoom out, the origins might not be as significant? (That last part is a bit of a devil’s advocate take)

For Stagecoach & CMA Fest at Nissan Stadium, (haven’t played Coachella) they have a team that takes a 1 to 1 multi from our board and they mix for the live stream. It’s equivalent to having a house guy mix every band. 

We worked really hard to make sure they never got our raw feed (which they wanted) and only got post mixer feed (which helps but levels are still totally whack.) 

Mixing for the room & mixing for the stream are def 2 different things, but they really haven’t figured that shit out yet.

author: Joel "Roomie" Berghult
content:
The no-brainer: If you feel they’re acting wrongly and there’s a negative impact on the world, take your business elsewhere and let them know your thoughts via non-public channels. 

Public campaigning or callouts are trickier and that come back to if you hurt your career and/or if you and your family are economically secure. It’s hard to argue for jeopardizing the well-being of those close to you for grand causes imo

In an era where albums are getting shorter and shorter and listening habits are heavily single and playlist-focused, Taylor got a mainstream audience to engage with a 31-song, 2-hour project.

author: spectrummasters
content: I recently saw a Steve albini interview where he was explaining that digital recordings are not forever . Tape he said was the safe medium for archiving . It piqued my interest as I hitherto believed digital storage represents a much better way to reproduce recordings in the future than a degrading tape . Yesterday I watched rob marksman (mtv news/hip hop journalist ) talking about digital not being permanent and we are at risk of breaking a chain of music histories being passed down in physical formats to generations to come due to streaming . If streaming companies fold in the future , no one would have any music magazines , videos , let alone singles / albums . It made me think of what Steve albini was saying . So at major labels ….are all the master recordings now digital files on a disk somewhere ?

author: spectrummasters
content: My take is , it’s not so much about “hard “ work , it’s about working , everyday , living and breathing that music thang. Which others call “hard work” . I don’t know if he would have said that . Those Minnesotan musicians ….prince , jam and Lewis , morris day etc were all as I understand it , living and working musicians …..from the james brown “you don’t work you don’t eat “ musical lineage . Which is to say, music was  a lane in a deeply segregated society that offered you a slim chamce of surviving a dearth of opportunity and finding a living. But goodness me  you had to work for it . All the greats , duke Ellington  Coltrane etc …..through howling wolf , muddy waters chuck berry james brown and up to princes era  , music wasn’t a luxury imho , it was a gift and one you had to hustle hard with to survive . In the spirit of this little video ,  re Prince and his work ethic … he wrote and wrote and wrote and wrote and finished and finished and finished  songs , as did jimmy jam and Terry Lewis . That work ethic that imho accepts you need to work to create brilliance. Hard . I think jam and Lewis said they expect one hit song for about every thirty they wrote and throw away . Constantly . That’s how I read “work ethic “

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
Is it worth bothering about sample clearance as an independent artist/producer who probably doesn't even have the means to do so? The way I see it, there are two possible outcomes: Your song doesn't blow up, no one cares enough to sue you, or the song does blow up, in which case the suing party will take a huge chunk, however, you'll probably still be left with a respectable sum after the fact
Think Juice WRLD Lucid Dreams, where Sting took 75% afaik or a similar number. 25% of Lucid Dream is still something I'd take without a second thought.

author: SoundsLikeJoe
content: I can see valid views from every angle...  Personally,  I would think that the position of the artist in the market (and their business plan) would dictate the approach they should take.  A professional with an audience?  Clear it first.  A hobbyist playing lottery odds for likes/shares and the chance of blowing up?  You've got nothing to lose and no money to afford clearance...   so pirate mode if you have too (fwiw - I don't recommend this but punk recognize punk)

author: Dereck Blackburn
content: Without telling the story about two years ago I had my first “bad” client. They were in the middle of building a house (unknown to me) and decided this would be a great time to manage that project but also make a record with me. Because I was under the impression that studios were financially out of reach for this person, I worked at half my usual rate and allowed them to give me a small deposit to start working together. MY MISTAKE.  Every time they came to the studio they were stressed out and unfocused. I did my best to make their home recordings sound great but there was very little good communication and it ended up that when I sent a mix over, I got a 8 paragraph dump about how nothing is working out, the mix was nothing they would ever release, then proceeded to call me a bunch of names - just taking out all their frustration on me. I zipped up all the work I had done so far and sent it over saying I think it’s best if we went our separate ways, you can do what you like with what we’ve done so far - I don’t want any credits at all. Since then it’s motivated me to make sure that I am following my process and OVERcommunicating every step of the way to be sure there’s no confusion about the work I do with clients. I learned that this former client bad mouthed me to a few artists and I lost some work because of it. Eventually work got back to normal and it’s been steady rocking ever since. The memory of how I felt motivated me everyday to be better than the day before, no joke - I know there’s going to be bad days here and there but I’ll be damned if I ever let someone take advantage of me like that again.
